Dear sir,

I beg to acknowledge yours of the 5th instant re heating of the Addition at the Kenora Indian Residential School.

When I was in Ottawa, I pointed out to Mr. Perrier that one of the rooms on the third floor of the school, occupied by one of the Staff Sisters had no radiator. During the Fall and Spring, this room is habitable but it is hardly so during the cold winter months. In view of this, I am sure that the Department will wish to reconsider its decision and that it will at least have a small radiator installed in that room. The addition of this small radiator will not materially decrease the efficiency of the plant as far as the school is concerned and will make the room referred to above more habitable. It is really too much to ask of anyone in our northern country, to occupy a room that is not heated and I am sure that the Department is fully aware of this.

So, although I am not urging the expenditure of any large sum on the Kenora School Heating Plant, I nevertheless am of the opinion that some radiation should be installed in the above room.

Hoping that you will give this matter early and favorable consideration, I remain,

Yours truly,

THE REVEREND OBLATE FATHERS

Toronto, Dec. 18, 1931.

Dear Sir:

Re: Sewage Disposal for the Indian Residential School, Kenora.

We are in receipt of your letter of the 9th instant, together with report on the proposed sewage disposal system for the above school.

After reviewing this report we are of the opinion that Scheme No.1 (the cheaper of the two) with certain modifications can be made quite satisfactory for this purpose. We understand that the population here is about 75 persons. We feel that the design should be made for a population of 100.

Utilizing both tanks in Scheme No.1 should provide sufficient sedimentation and storage for this purpose. We are not certain, however, from the report as to just what is intended to be done with the second tank. It is stated in the report that a syphon chamber will be constructed. There is some doubt as to whether it was the intention to utilize the entire second tank as a syphon chamber, or to use only part of it. We feel that it would be more desirable to use both of these tanks for sedimentation purposes and to construct a small syphon chamber as an addition to this. This would not be an expensive item.

In connection with the disposal bed, it would appear that the bed suggested for Scheme No.1, with the addition of some extra rows of tiles would be made satisfactory. You have in this bed now approximately 1000' of distribution tiles. We believe it would be advisable to increase this number to probably 1500'.

We are also interested in the method suggested for the disposal of the laundry wastes. It would not be satisfactory to discharge this into the water without treatment. We see no reason why it cannot be passed through the septic tank system. This amount of waste should not upset the condition in the tanks, particularly if both are used for sedimentation purposes. April 22, 1935.

Memorandum: Honourable Thomas S. Murphy,

The Roman Catholic Indian Residential School at Kenora is located close to the shore of a small bay of the Lake of the Woods about three miles from Kenora. There have been many complaints in the past few years from the Ontario Department of Health that the sewage from this School is contaminating to a great extent the water in the Lake of the Woods. The School is located about half a mile above the intake of the Kenora water supply system, and at the present time the Kenora water supply is being chlorinated to such a degree as to render it very disagreeable to drink, and still the Ontario Department of Health is not satisfied as to its safety. Steps are being taken to prevent the pollution of the water of the Lake and the Residential School is considered to be a very grave offender in this respect. It is therefore necessary to arrange this year for alterations to the existing septic tank and the installing of a new filter bed.

Last year Mr. J.M. Cox of the Winnipeg office of the Dominion Water Power and Reclamation Service made a survey and report as to what is required. He submitted two proposals. The first scheme provides for making use of the existing septic tank, with minor changes, and the entire construction of a new disposal bed. This scheme will cost approximately $1,600.00.

Scheme No. 2 provides for a more complete disposal system, more in conformity with modern installation. It involves the complete scrapping of the existing disposal system and the construction of an entirely new one. The estimated cost of Scheme No. 2 is $4,000.00.

A copy of Mr. Cox's report was submitted to the Director of the Sanitary Engineering Division of the Ontario Department of Health, and they reported that, with a few modifications, they considered Scheme No. 1 would be satisfactory, and the Architect of the Department also recommends that this scheme be adopted.

$1,600.00 has provided in this year's estimates for this work and if you approve Mr. Cox will be asked to proceed with the work, the same to be under his supervision.

Acting Deputy Superintendent General.

Dear Sir:

I have this morning had a conversation with Mr. Gow of Winnipeg in connection with the above.

I am accordingly advising you of the discussion we have had with reference to the disposal system to be constructed at this institution. The bed for disposal of the effluent measures 40 feet x 120 feet. In the present arrangement the tiles for distribution of the effluent from the septic tank are laid 4 feet apart. It has been suggested that the same size bed be used but that an additional two rows of tiles, each 120 feet long, be employed to distribute the sewage. This will give approximately 1500 feet of drainage tiles.

The other point raised was the question of the syphon chamber. As was proposed on the original plans the syphon chamber was to be made a part of the final settling tank. It was pointed out in our previous correspondence that it would be more desirable to utilize this tank completely for settling purposes and to construct a new syphon chamber outside this tank. In going over the plans it was felt that it would cost very little, if any more, to build a syphon chamber adjoining this settling tank. The one wall of the settling tank could be employed in the construction of the syphon chamber.

In view of the fact that this tank would be quite shallow and not large, the cost would be practically negligible. According to Mr. Gow it may not be feasible to do this when examination of the local conditions is made. The final question in connection with this was that an additional syphon chamber would be constructed if local conditions permit. If not then the arrangement shown on Mr. Gow's plan would be adhered to.

Ottawa, August 15, 1932.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 26th ultimo, regarding the improvements required at the Kenora Indian Residential School and enumerating same in the order of importance, as decided by the Reverend Principal and yourself, together with an estimate of the cost.

In this connection I have to say that the Department will approve of an expenditure, which must not exceed the sum of $8,000, for the labour and materials in carrying out the work considered the most urgent by the Principal and yourself. The Department would suggest that the painting of the outbuildings, the decorating of the interior of the main building and the repairing of the wharf should be among the improvements carried out. You should arrange for the purchase of the materials required from firms on the list to receive consideration. With reference to the labour to be employed, you should consult Mr. Frank McManus, of Kenora. It is considered that all work should be carried out by day labour. Please keep proper time sheets, in triplicate, of the labour employed. These should be signed by the individual labourers and certified by yourself. If necessary, an advance could be sent you to pay labour. These improvements should be undertaken at an early date.

With reference to the 40 mattresses required, I shall be pleased if you will state definitely the sizes of the beds for which they are needed and the number of each size. Consideration will then be given to placing an order here for the supplying of these.

In reply to your letter of the 6th instant, with reference to the work to be undertaken in improving the sewage disposal plant, I have to say that an accountable cheque, amounting to $300, has been sent you to pay labour. You should keep proper time sheets, in triplicate, and have them signed by the individual labourers and certified by yourself in accounting for the disbursement of this advance. When forwarding vouchers in triplicate, properly certified, covering the cost of the improvements, you should state definitely the work that was undertaken.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKinnon,
Secretary.

Frank Edwards, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.

With reference to the 10% reduction as mentioned by the Indian Agent, I beg to say that the Auditor General and the Comptroller of the Treasury have ruled that the spirit of the Act will be complied with in casual labour so long as the rates paid this fiscal year are at least 10% lower than the rates paid for similar classes of labour during the past year.

The rate of 50 cents per hour for labourers, and 70 cents for teamsters is more than 10% less than that paid for similar work last year, and no further reduction should therefore be made. I am also advised by the Department of Labour that 70 cents is the current rate of wages for teamsters in Regina. Sept. 20, 1932.

Honorable Mr. Parkman,

With reference to your memorandum of the 2nd of September, with regard to the wages being paid on the work at the Kenora Co. School, at Kenora, Ont., I beg to quote from a letter received from Captain Edwards, Indian Agent, regarding the wages as follows:

"We obtained the rates from the Department of Public Works at Fort William that went into effect on August 1st, 1932, the rates being as follows:

Labourers - $5 cents per hour.
Teamsters, Team and Wagon, $6 cents per hour, with a deduction of 10% on all wages and salaries for labour employed by the Department of Public Works, and an 8 hour day to apply.

We have paid the men at this rate, but yesterday Mr. F. J. Maclean handed us a letter dated the 1st instant from the Minister of Labour, a copy of which is enclosed herewith. Dear Sir:

Replying to your letter 129-1-5 of 5th inst., re improvements at the Kenora R.C. Residential School.

The Principal informs us that he has a large amount of the painting of the out-buildings done as he anticipated the authority of the Department, and has spent roughly $200. on this work. He says that this is the first time these buildings have been painted, although authority was granted for this work two or three years ago. It was left over at that time as it was too late in the year to do anything, and authority has not been granted since. He would like to get the expenditure refunded.

We will go ahead with the repairs to the Wharf, the building of the Cattle Shed, and will do an amount of draining and grading the road to the school to the value of about $150.00. This is an imperative need.

The Principal would also like to have the Pump House and the two sheds wired for electric light, and estimates the cost of this as $100.

This would leave a balance of roughly $550. which the Principal would like expended on clearing land.

The above, the Principal informs us, is the most imperative work required, and we would be glad to know if this meets with your approval.
of the expenditure available, viz., $730. General Superintendent of Indian Affairs,

Dear Sir,

The following is a list of the requirements (for 1933-34) for the Indian Schools under our jurisdiction:

1. The principal has complained on several occasions of defective heating. The matter was previously taken up with the Department and action was promised but so far nothing has been done. It is possible that for a relatively small amount the heating could be improved to a point where there would be no further reason for complaint on the part of the staff.

2. There is very little land suitable for farming. The Department in the last few years has spent some money in clearing land for this purpose. An additional grant of $200.00 would be of great assistance in this connection.

3. The present store house is too small and an addition of 16 x 16 would be greatly appreciated. The principal estimates that this could be done for $800.00.

4. The painting of the outbuildings is not complete and an estimated amount of $150.00 is needed for this purpose. The interior of the building was painted only in part last year and it is estimated that $300.00 more are required for this purpose.

5. The fence between the school property and the land adjoining it to the north was not properly laid out in the first place and a correction of the fence line is desired. It is estimated that this would cost $300.00.

6. The road from the village to the school is in very bad condition and during bad weather is almost impassable. Drainage and grading to the amount of $300.00 is asked in this connection.

(Sgd.) J. O. Plourde, O.M.I.,
619 McDermot St.,

Ottawa, February 3, 1933.

Sir:

The Superintendent General of Indian Affairs received a communication from P. Dubois, Chief of the Fire Department, Kenora, regarding the matter of fire protection at Indian residential schools. He does not refer to any school by name but states in his letter as follows:

"... The conditions found around some of them is deplorable, and it is no wonder that they burn up so frequently. Allow me to put up to you one instance. I will not mention any names, but I can produce the facts in full if necessary. I found hand chemicals, the two and a half gallon size, supposed to be in readiness for business in case of fire, in such shape that they would not even shoot a drop of water. In examining them I found that the metal cork usually used for coking the acid bottle setting on the head of the bottle was the original rubber cork still in the neck of the bottle. It had never been taken out and naturally no acid would flow if the machine was tipped over for use. The one setting up these machines did not even know why and how the metal corks were used. I might say that metal corks replace the rubber ones when the machine is set for use, and these machines had not been touched for at least over twelve years, when in reality they should be charged yearly."

I would request that you interview the Fire Chief and ascertain from him the school referred to in his letter. If the school is located in your agency, you should immediately make an inspection of the fire equipment and its condition and report to the Department. The condition referred to by the Fire Chief in connection with the extinguishers on hand should be remedied at the earliest possible moment. These extinguishers should be placed in a condition ready for immediate use. If any refills are required, you may purchase same forwarding accounts in the usual manner covering the cost.

Please report regarding the fire escapes, stating whether they are kept in a satisfactory condition or if any repairs or improvements are required. Your recommendation, together with the cost involved, should be given.

Your early attention to this matter will be appreciated.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Frank Edwards, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.
KENORA, Ont., February 6th, 1933

Captain F. Edwards,
Indian Agent,

Town.

RE R.C. Residential Indian School

Dear Captain:

In reference to the items we were discussing in connection with the conditions at the R.C. Industrial Indian school as mentioned in correspondence from the headquarters of your Department, I wish to state the conditions I referred to in my letter to the Minister were the conditions that we dealt with some three years ago and which are now in excellent shape due to the very prompt manner in which my recommendations were given attention to through your very kind efforts. I might state that this building is out of my jurisdiction as it is outside of our town limits but through your intercession I was given the authority to give not only this school but the Cecilia Jeffrey school as well a good thorough inspection from a fire protection point of view and I am pleased to state that practically every suggestion that I made in this connection was very satisfactory attended to in every respect and that now both these schools are in very good condition and are periodically visited and I am sure that I am only too well pleased to be always at your service at any time that any question may crop up where the safety of the occupants and property are at stake for I certainly am one of the last Citizens of Kenora that wants to see a fire occur in any one of these institutions for, as I said before although they are out of our district we shall only be too pleased to render any assistance we can if an emergency occurred that we would be notified of.

I am sure that the occurrence we experienced a few years ago at the Cecilia Jeffrey school where our assistance aided in keeping down the damage to nearby structures when the school stable burned will convince you that we are always at your service.

Respectfully submitted by yours truly,

Chief Fire Dept.
Kenora, Ontario,
February, 7th, 1933.

Dear Sir,

Replying to your letter 129-1-5 of 3rd inst., re communication from the Kenora Fire Chief to the Superintendent General, Indian Affairs.

We have today interviewed the Town Fire Chief, F. Dubois, and he informs us that the school referred to in his communication, was the Kenora R.C. Residential, in this Agency. Several years ago we thought it advisable to ask the Fire Chief if he would make an annual inspection of our schools, to make sure the equipment and necessary protection were in good order. It was found at that time, that one of the Hand Chemical Machines was not in good shape, through the rubber cork having been left in instead of being taken out when the machine was installed. Every year since that time periodical inspections have been made by the Fire Chief and his Staff, and I have been present with him throughout. Although he is not paid by Town limits, the Fire Chief has been glad to make these inspections, for which he has made no charge, even using his own car for the trips. After his inspections we get a letter from him, making any suggestions for improvements he thinks advisable, and in every case the suggestions have been carried out.

The Fire Escapes at the School are now in good condition, with the exception of some slight alterations to be made at the Cecilia Jeffrey School, which are authorized, and will be made as soon as the weather moderates.

I have been Chairman for the last two years of the Civic Affairs Committee of the Kenora Board of Trade and have conducted and marked all examination papers for the Town of Kenora Firemen, and have signed and forwarded the certificates to those who have passed. The Fire Chief is very keen on his job, and the Town have won both the Dominion and Provincial Fire Protection Association, Trophies for Towns of 5000 to 25,000 population. The Dominion Trophy last year, and the Provincial Trophy for the last six years.

We inclose a letter received from the Fire Chief, which explains his letter to the Superintendent General, and trust the above is the information required.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]
Indian Agent.

Assistant Deputy & Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.
February 11, 1933.

Memorandum:

In further reference to your memorandum of the 30th ultimo and my reply of the 2nd instant, regarding the communication received by the Honourable the Minister from the Chief of the Fire Department, Kenora, Ont., concerning fire prevention and fire equipment and drawing attention to the conditions found by him, I have to say that this matter was referred to Mr. Frank Edwards, Indian Agent, Kenora, for a report. He was requested to interview the Fire Chief and ascertain from him the school referred to in his letter.

For your information, I attach hereto the reply of Mr. Edwards, together with copy of a communication he received from the Fire Chief. I am sure you will observe from the correspondence that the Fire Chief was not referring to conditions which obtain at the present time. The fire equipment at the two residential schools at Kenora is kept in good, serviceable condition.

Deputy Superintendent General.

Dear Sir:

The Principal of the Kenora Residential R.C. School reports that owing to the heavy rains the Sewage Disposal Bed at his School has been damaged, by the amount of water running from the high banks behind and some of the pipes of the disposal bed are broken and the bed washed out, causing the fluid to come up out the ground and run into the Lake. Dr. Ferguson our Medical Officer went to look over the situation this morning and informs us that something must be done immediately as the water runs into the Lake just over the intake of the Town's water supply.

Messrs. Kelly & Kimberley inform us that in their opinion it will cost in the neighbourhood of $400.00 to put the field in first class shape, and if this is not done at once, there is liable to be damage done to the whole field. If the face of the disposal bed had been rip rapped this would not have happened, but of course it was unforeseen, and we have had very heavy rains. We have given instructions to Kelly and Kimberley to make a temporary repair and will be glad if you will send your instructions direct to the Principal, as we leave for the North on Annuity payments tomorrow morning at 3 A.M., and will not be back in Kenora till nearly the end of the month.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Sir:

Re: R. C. Indian School near Kenora.

As requested in your letter of the 8th instant, I examined conditions of the sewage disposal bed at the R. C. Indian School at Kenora on the 16th instant. Both Captain Edwards, Indian Agent, and Dr. Ferguson, Medical Health Officer, were absent from Kenora on Treaty Payments, but I found that temporary repair work was in progress under the direction of Kelly and Kimberley, Contractors of Kenora. I was given to understand that temporary repairs were authorized by Captain Edwards at the insistence of the Medical Health Officer. These temporary repairs were merely to prevent further deterioration in the event of further heavy rainfall.

The sewage disposal bed at this school was of necessity laid in a restricted area on the slope toward the lake in front of the school and in a slight depression where rock was not too close to the surface. The disposal bed was apparently constructed in accordance with the plans which did not provide for rip-rap facing on the south and west slopes, exposed to prevent erosion from wave action on the lake side. It was hoped that the surface drainage would not erode the slopes of the disposal bed, but would follow a natural drainage depression leading immediately south of the bed. However, heavy rainfall this spring caused considerable drainage around the bed, eroding away part of the south and west slopes of the bed and possibly exposing the voids in one or two places. It now appears as if additional expense should have been incurred at the time the disposal bed was constructed and the south and west slopes of the bed protected with a wall of broken rock, carefully laid so as to contain only small voids. Furthermore, cut-off ditches should have been cut along the slope immediately above the disposal bed, so as to bypass the run-off from the slope above.

I would suggest that this work be now carried out. The entire south and west slopes of the disposal bed should have loose rock facing, carefully laid and following the original slope right up to the top of the disposal bed. The general level of the disposal bed should then be brought up to the original elevation. Cut-off ditches should be constructed to prevent the run-off from the slope above the system. Every effort should be made to effect a growth of grass on the disposal bed. This rock facing should consist of flat broken rock placed horizontally with the voids carefully filled with small stone so as to make a wall with a thickness of about ten inches. Reverend Principal,

Reverend Sir:

The Fire Chief reports that at your school two 5 Gal. water pumps were empty and not in use. He recommends that one Thermin be kept handy for the laundry-boiler room and one for the laundry room. One Gardene Soda & Acid chemical for the hallway of the first floor and one at the end of the hallways of the other floors. One Pyrene should be kept in the kitchen and one in the office. The John Hanville hand extinguishers should be installed in the class rooms and some in the dormitories. One 5 gal. water tank should be kept in the work shop building and one in the stable and these two machines filled with a non-freezeable liquid. In the basement the hose there at the present time is quite sufficient to take care of that section of the building, but this place should be kept in better order, and wood or chips kept away from the furnace. He recommends that a piece of asbestos about 1" thick 2 feet wide and 4 feet high be placed next to the wood box. In the kitchen stove, the bottom of the ash pit should be covered with fire clay, as there being no ash tray, the heat may cause trouble in this spot. The Chief further suggests you should appoint some reliable employee to keep all the fire appliances, including fire escapes and exits in proper order and also see that the extinguishers are not interfered with, and replaced, at least once a year. Fire buckets used formerly are worn out and should be replaced as they may come in handy for bush or fires near the water front.

Would you kindly attend to the Chief's suggestions and we will write Ottawa for authority to purchase fire buckets, asbestos and the fire clay as soon as possible.

The school bell could be used as a fire alarm.

Yours faithfully,

Indian Agent.
FIRE DEPARTMENT

KENORA, ONT., November 3rd, 1933

Captain F. Edwards,
Indian Agent,

Town.

Dear Sir:

After our recent inspection of the two Indian residential schools I wish to submit as per your request the following report on the conditions found as well as suggestions for improvements on some of the equipment in use.

At St Anthony's R.C. School the conditions found were that two of the water five gallon hand pumps were empty and not in use, in other sections of the building but the basement I would recommend that one Thermene be kept handy for the laundry boiler room and one for the laundry room, also one Guardene soda and acid chemical for the hallway of the first floor and one at the end of the hallways on the other floors, one Pyrene should be kept in the kitchen and one in the office, the John Manville hand extinguishers should be installed in the class rooms and some in the dormitories, one five gallon water tank should be kept in the work shop building and one in the stable, these two machines can be kept filled with a non freeze liquid in these buildings, in the basement the hose there at present is quite sufficient to take care of that section of the building but I would recommend that this place be kept in better order and wood or chips be kept away from the furnaces.

I would recommend that a piece of asbestos about a quarter of an inch in thickness be placed next to the wood box and the oven fire box, this piece of asbestos should be about two feet wide and at least four feet high, in the kitchen, the bottom of the ash pit should be covered with fire clay as there is no ash pan and the heat from the hot ashes may cause trouble in this spot.

As regards to a fire alarm system there is a small steel triangle already installed which is loud enough to be heard during class hours but it may be possible to install a regular striker on the large bell on the building which would be heard all over the premises as a fire bell and as a fire signal it would be heard by everyone both inside and out in all the other sections of the institution, the rope for this striker could extend through the building to the lower floor and I believe it would serve to advantage in this respect.

The Pastor in charge should appoint some reliable employees to keep all fire protection appliances including the fire escapes and exits always in proper order and should see that the extinguishers are not meddled with and recharged at least once a year, the fire buckets used formally are worn out and should be replaced as they may come handy for bush or fires near the water front.

Yours truly, F. Dubois, Fire Chief.
Ottawa, November 22, 1933.

Dear Sir,

Would you be kind enough to write to the Department and tell them we have no residence for our employees. Then we had no night watchman the workmen slept in the loft of the carpenters' shop, but since the School has been obliged to employ a night watchman, the old sleeping quarters are unsuitable because the watchman complains that with the noise going on in the shop it is impossible for him to sleep.

In order to correct this situation, the Oblate Fathers are offering to the School the use of a house which they own on a lot about 200 feet distant from the School property. This house was at one time the residence of the Principal, but as it has not been used for many years, considerable repairs have to be made to it so that it may be habitable. I believe that the material needed for these repairs would amount to about $475.00. If the Department would assume this expense we would assume the labor cost for same.

Will you also ask the Department to kindly give us a Hot water Tank to replace the old one we have in the kitchen, which is completely worn out and must be replaced. The capacity of this Tank is 60 gallons and would cost not more than $45.00.

The reasons why I did not mention these items at the same time with the other estimates are the following: for the water Tank, it did not seem to be necessary at the time; as to the employees' house, the night watchman was not complaining too much then, but now he says he cannot sleep when they are working downstairs, and no one can blame him for that.

Hoping that you will kindly forward the above request to the Department, I remain Sir,

Yours faithfully

KENORA INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL

Kenora, Ontario,
June 7th, 1934.

Dear Sir,

We find it absolutely necessary to provide sleeping quarters for our night watchman. Since the creation of the position, the night watchman has had sleeping quarters in the loft of the carpenter shop, as there is absolutely no room for him in the school proper. These sleeping quarters are far from being comfortable. Each night watchman that we have had to date has left more or less because he had no proper place to sleep during the day. The noise of the gasoline engine, as well as the continuous hammering going on in the carpenter shop, makes sleep impossible.

I quite understand that the building of a house for our night watchman is out of the question at the present time owing to the curtailment of all expenditures that is being going on in the Department; but would it be possible for the Department to allow the school a sufficient amount of money to buy the material to repair the building situated on the school grounds which, at one time, was used as a residence by the Principal? I am quite sure that, for the sum of $250 or, at most, $300., this building could be put in fair condition. I will pay all wages out of the grant.

I had hoped not to have to bother the Department with this matter but, as my night watchman threatens to leave me unless I provide him with proper sleeping quarters, I think it is my duty to ask the Department to assist in this regard.

Hoping that you will give this matter your immediate consideration,

Yours very truly,

J.E. Baillargeon

R.C. Indian Residential School: We find this building in a well kept condition, pupils healthy looking and contented. We would recommend, however, that the two porches on West side be demolished and replaced, as posts, railing and floors are in a decayed and dangerous condition. It is also our opinion that an additional fire escape is very necessary.

OCEILIA JEFFREY INDIAN SCHOOL: We find this building to be well managed and attendance above the average. The building itself, however, is badly in need of painting, both inside and out and is deteriorating on this account. The sashes are shrunk and windows need weatherstripping and caulking. If this were done a huge saving could be effected in fuel. We also note that sewage from seepage field is rising to surface and running into lake endangering the purity of the water supply. If this condition is not remedied an epidemic might result. We would, therefore, recommend that additional tile piping be added to existing distribution field to obviate this nuisance by increasing the area of seepage field.

St. Joseph's and the Kenora General Hospitals:

As these buildings and equipment are daily inspected by the Public and have been inspected by preceding Grand Jurors; and as this inspection would add to the work of the staff and discomfort of the patients we decided that this inspection would well be dispensed with.

All of which is respectfully submitted.

George K. Kimberley.

My Dear Mr. Phelan:

I am just back from Kenora, Ontario. I went down at the request of Rev. Father Baillargeon to talk over the matter of repairs to his school.

As you know, there is provision for the building of a Hog House for the estimated amount of $900. While this is a needed improvement, Father Baillargeon is of the opinion that it would be better to postpone the building of the Hog House and to use the sum provided for this purpose for very urgent repairs to the school, particularly the floors in two of the classrooms and in the boys dormitory. These floors are of fir and were put in when the school was first built. They show considerable wear; in fact, in some places they are worn right through to the rough floor. Keeping these floors clean is almost an impossibility; it is moreover quite dangerous for the girls, as in the process of cleaning the floors they injure their hands with splinters.

The school has no garage; the automobile now used by the school for trucking is in the open and suffers considerable depreciation from being exposed to all kinds of weather. Father Baillargeon believes that with the sum of $900 provided for the Hog Pen that he could not only put in new floors where such are urgently needed, but that he could also build a one-car garage.

These matters were submitted to your agent, Captain Edwards, and he has approved this substitution but we would not like to proceed without the authority of the department.

Hoping that you may be able to give us an immediate and favorable answer, I remain,

Yours very truly,

With reference to your 109-13 of the 8th instant, I beg to say that you may make immediate arrangements for repairs to the floors of the junior classroom and the boys' dormitory in the Kenora Indian Residential School. You may, also, arrange for the purchase of the material and the erection of a garage. The repairs to the deck and road are also authorized and work should begin at once.

The total expenditure in connection with the above should not exceed $1,850. An accountable cheque for $100., also a supply of labour return forms, will be forwarded to you.

Materials should be purchased from firms on the approved list and any extra labour required should, also, be engaged by you.

With regard to the repairs to the heating plant, the Department is communicating with Inspector Hamilton in order that he may arrange to have The Standard Plumbing and Heating Company do this work.

A copy of this letter is being sent to the Principal of the Kenora School.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. Mackenzie,
Secretary.

Frank Edwards, Esq.,
Indian Agent,

Dear Sir:

Reference our letter of 8th inst. re appropriation for the Kanora Residential R.O. School.

We have today again seen the Principal of the school and he informs us we made an error in paragraph 3 regarding the $900.00 for the New Hog Pen.

The school authorities had to leave this matter to a later date and they wish the $900.00 spent on a new floor in the workshop and repairs to the floor of the junior class room and the erection of a Garage for the school car.

Some of these matters were taken up with Mr. Phalen when he was here, and we believe authority was given for the floor in the junior class room. Will this be an extra allotment or will it have to come out of the $900.00?

An appropriation will be included in the next estimates for the floor in the boys dormitory.

October 25, 1936.

Sir:

Re: R. C. Indian School, Kenora, Ont.

Upon the occasion of my visit to Kenora on October 22nd and 23rd, I visited the R. C. Indian School at Kenora to ascertain the condition of the sewage disposal bed at that point.

This disposal bed, as you are possibly aware, was constructed on the water's edge of the Lake of the Woods and was protected on the shore side by a hand laid rock rip-rap. The disposal bed has now become covered with a growth of grass and as far as appearances went, is operating very efficiently. It was noticed, however, that a portion of the rip-rap on the water's edge had become displaced and needs repairing. This repair work could now be possibly done at a cost of $10.00 or $15.00, whereas it will possibly cost $100.00 if allowed to deteriorate much further. I would, therefore, suggest that the Indian Agent at Kenora - Captain Edwards, be instructed at the very earliest possible date, to have this rip-rap replaced.

Your obedient servant,

It has been laid only about 1' below the water level prevailing in April and May and at the present time, for a considerable distance from the shore. The fact that the old pipe line never froze is no reason to assume that the new one will not, especially since the old pipe is set nearly 9' lower than the new pipe and another pipe. Captain Edwards,  
Indian Agent,  
Kenora, Ontario.

Dear Captain:

Following our examination of the new pump and pipe line installed at the R. C. Indian School at Kenora, I have studied the Campbell Heating Company's proposals, made in writing to you under date of April 30, 1930. This firm reported that the lake level was about 22 feet below the pump and recommended their "First Proposal" as "the proper and thorough way to install this job", and "For the reason that this pump motor and suction line are of the proper capacity to do the job thoroughly and depending upon these reports and recommendations, I understand you advised that the work be proceeded with. Later this Company demanded and secured an additional $600.00 above their original offer for doing the work. Mr. Campbell now states that the lake level is 25' 8" below the pump. I would here like to point out that on September 13th the lake level was 105.40 and on no day during the month of April, 1930 did the lake level reach this elevation; it was always lower. Had the suction lift been only 22 feet and had the 4" pipe line been properly laid below the frost line and otherwise properly laid, in all probability the system would have worked, but, however, with little margin of safety. I am now assuming that the suction lift has been found to be nearly 25 feet. The Campbell Heating Company, acting in the capacity of Advisory Engineers and Consulting Contractors, have therefore the responsibility of seeing that the system is made to work in a "thorough way".

Assuming the suction lift to be 25 feet, I am of the opinion that taking into consideration friction losses in the pipe line, and the possibility of still lower water in the lake, that a new pump as installed cannot be made to serve satisfactorily and that no time should be wasted in attempting to make it do so. The pump and motor are efficient but not dependable against a suction lift in excess of 22 feet when there are several friction losses. The remedy, therefore, is to decrease the suction lift by lowering the pump. Being as it is necessary to move the pump it would be advisable to lower it sufficiently to ensure sufficient operation. I would suggest that a new pump house be erected immediately over the check valve now installed below the old pump house. This pump house should be 8' x 10' with an 8" wall, with an 8" concrete floor slab resting on gravel with wooden trap door giving access to the check valve. I would set the motor and pump as low as possible but resting on a concrete platform, say 4" or 6" above the concrete floor.

On the other hand should the inspection reveal breaks in the pipe line, it would be necessary to raise the whole line to the surface and this could most readily be done with an ice cover.

When this suction line was laid the water of Lake of the Woods was approximately four feet lower than it is at present. The pipe line extends for approximately 650 feet out into the lake from water's edge and if breaks have occurred the repairing of the line will be a difficult matter and will entail considerable expense. An examination of the profile of the water line leads me to the belief that if a break has occurred that such break might be approximately 325 feet out from the shore line. Further consideration, however, will be given to this matter and a trip will be made to Kenora to consult with people there who have had more experience in dealing with such matters than the writer. Sir:

This will acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 21st instant with reference to the water intake at the Roman Catholic Indian School at Kenora, Ontario. It is noted that sand is being drawn into the pump and as a consequence considerable trouble has developed.

The writer was at Kenora on October 22nd last in connection with a visit relating to the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian School and upon that occasion also visited the Roman Catholic Indian School - being interested in learning how the water intake was laid as we were then considering the laying of a suction line at Lebret, Saskatchewan. Mr. Kimberley, who had something to do with the laying of the suction line in 1920, informed me that the pump was drawing in sand at that time - that is, in October, 1920. Accordingly, the present trouble can be attributed to the same cause and it is not considered necessary to make an immediate visit to the school and examine the intake. Severe winter conditions are being experienced and similar conditions can be expected to prevail until late in March, preventing inspection and repair work being carried out except at great inconvenience to the school and heavy expense to the Department.

This office had nothing to do with the placing of this suction line in 1920, but as the accompanying copy of a letter written to Captain Edwards on September 16, 1920 will reveal, we were rather critical of the pumping arrangements and also of the laying of the suction lines. Our suggestions regarding the pumping arrangements were ignored and when the suction line was tested immediately at a later date Mr. Rose of this office made a profile of the suction line pipe and also located its position on the lake bottom with reference to the school location. This profile, when plotted, revealed that it would be possible for many air pockets to form in the pipe line.

It is noted that Captain Edwards has examined the situation and claims that the sand is in the water and is drawn into the pumps. In our opinion, however, the water of Lake of the Woods at that particular location is not subject to agitation and furthermore that the end of the pipe line is resting upon a rock bottom. It is our opinion, therefore, that the end of the pipe line is either immersed partially in sand now or that breaks have occurred at one or more points along the suction line and that sand is being drawn in from the lake bottom.

Department of Indian Affairs.

Dear Sir;

As requested by your local agent in his letter dated the 16th of May, I am forwarding to you the specifications required with reference to road work and other minor constructions on the school property.

For general information I am stating that this road referred to branches off from the route built to accommodate the Golf course and the Cameron Camps and leads to the school covering a distance of half a mile more or less. This portion of the road has been considerably improved in recent years, but owing to the lack of funds it was built too narrow and moreover was not completed to the school. Personally, I do not think it is necessary to broaden the road along the whole course. For my part I deem it sufficient to make four or five meeting places for vehicles so as to ensure more safety. With regard to the last portion of the road which was not completed and which trails from the entry of the school property to the house—a distance I would say of two hundred yards—I understand that to make a good job it would be a costly proposition, owing to the fact that rock barriers lie across the roadway. But I think it would be reasonable to spread a little gravel over this portion to ensure a better outlet during wet seasons.

Now I would not like to leave you under the impression that this road though leading to the school serves only the interests of the school. As a matter of fact this road is used as much if not more by our Indians who live on the reserve which lies beyond the school property leading towards the Devil's Gap.

These suggested restrictions upon road work would perhaps enable us to accomplish more of the proposed items. For instance the dock is decayed and calls for a complete renewal. It measures 30x12 ft., built of heavy log crib work and covered with plank. In connection with the dock and surrounding the two boat houses, there are three sections of side walk which are badly rotted. This would call for an expenditure of more than $250.

Dear Sirs: Re St. Mary's Indian School, Kenora.

At the request of the principal of this school, I have made a check of the water pumping system. His reason for having the system checked was that sand and dirt were being taken in through the pump lines, and the pump was slowing up and losing its prime.

Our check-up showed that the 4" iron intake pipe is broken off at a distance of 150 feet from the shore line. The original end of this suction line where the water should be taken in is 900 feet from the shore line. At the point where the breakage is, the water is 9 feet deep. The pipe is enclosed in a wooden crib and the crib is loaded with dirt filling. In order to repair this break, a coffer dam would have to be constructed. This dam would have to be long enough to work at a 20 foot length of 4" iron pipe. Making this dam would be a real job, as the bottom of the lake at this point is mud. The crib work would have to be cut away before the dam could be put down.

I would estimate the cost of the dam and the repair to the pipe and the back filling of this crib at $2,000.00 or more. There is also always the chance that after this break has been repaired that other breaks may show up or develop, or with the weight of the dirt being put back in the crib the pipe may snap off again.

I would propose that in view of the outlined conditions that this pipe line be discarded and a new line of copper piping be put down to replace it. This line could be of smaller size, say 2½" or 2". This pipe would have some give and would fit down to the bottom of the lake. It could be placed in the water beside the present crib and very little additional frost covering would be required.

My dear Mr. Sutherland:

I am sorry to inform you that the water situation at the Kenora school requires immediate attention. I understand that Dr. Ferguson has forbidden the use of the present supply of water on account of the danger of contagion.

There is a break in the supply pipe 150 feet from the shore line. As this break is very close to the septic tank, it is feared that contaminated water is being pumped into the pressure tank in the basement of the school. That is the reason why Dr. Ferguson forbade the school authorities to use any lake water.

As the school children are now on their vacation, the inconvenience caused by this break is not very serious as water can be hauled for ordinary culinary purposes but, as soon as the children return, this will be an impossible task and besides, there might be the danger of the children and members of the staff drinking the contaminated water.

Will you be good enough to have this matter investigated immediately? Mr. Charles Batchford, of Kenora, made the survey of the whole system of water supply and has submitted a price for the laying of a new pipe line. Mr. Batchford has done considerable work for the school in the past and his prices were always fair and the quality of his work very satisfactory. As he is a local man, we are quite sure that if he were given the contract for this work, it would be done quickly and to the satisfaction of the department.

Hoping that you will attend to this matter without further delay, we remain,

Yours very truly,

Sir:

As requested by your letter of July 28th, I visited Kenora in connection with the water intake at the R. C. Indian School.

Recently the Principal of the School had a local firm examine the intake and I believe this examination revealed a break in the pipe line about 150 feet from the shore and no doubt the water supply has been taken from that point rather than from the end of the line about 700 feet from shore. The break in the line was located under the crib which protects the line from freezing during low water - this cribwork at that point being 10 to 15 feet in width and from 5 to 7 feet deep and is submerged at the existing lake level. The cribwork is filled with gravel, earth and possibly some rock and sheet piled at the sides.

The intake was laid in 1930 and a new pumping unit was also installed at the same time. At low lake elevation the pipe line has very little protection from freezing but to date no trouble has been experienced. The present pipe should still be in serviceable condition but it may be possible that other breaks exist in the line cut from the one located.

We would suggest that the existing intake pipe line be repaired. This will involve removing the cribwork protection at the location of the break and repairing the break by means of rubber hose couplings. Tests must then be made to determine if other breaks occur. Removing the cribwork will be expensive, involving the use of drag line and possibly dynamite. After the break has been sealed it will be necessary to rebuild the cribwork protection.

This office was not connected in any way with the placing of this intake in 1930 but while carrying out other work at the school later did locate the pipe line, secure a profile of the same and locate the cribbing. A plan was prepared to show these details. It is necessary to make further examination of the pipe line now, also to examine more closely the work involved in getting at the break under the cribwork, etc. The results of these examinations will determine whether or not it is advisable to relay the pipe line.

The writer endeavored to secure some reliable estimates of the probable costs of repairing the existing line and also of laying a new line. The opinions of those questioned were apparently influenced by the desire to secure considerable work as they considered it would cost as much to repair the existing line as it would to lay a new line. The writer does not share their view and would recommend that the old line be repaired. The cost may exceed $1,000.00 but will be much less if suitable equipment is available to remove the cribwork.

J. T. Johnston, Esq.,
Director,
Dominion Water Power and Hydrometric Bureau,
Ottawa, Ontario.

We have made further investigations regarding the water supply intake at the above mentioned institution. Compressed air was forced through the pipe line, area of crib work was determined and soundings taken to determine depth of water.

It was ascertained that a major break in the pipe line existed 118 feet from the pump house and a minor leakage was located about 70 feet from the pump house. Because of the major break 118 feet out, it was impossible to determine with air whether breaks occur beyond that point, but there probably are several breaks. The cribwork extends 151 feet out from the pump house so both located breaks occur under this protective covering.

At present the water supply for the school is being obtained by means of the pump and pipe line in use prior to the new installation made in 1930. Sand, silt etc., is being drawn in and the pump will soon be useless. The pump, installed in 1930, will have to be overhauled before again being operated as the cylinder walls are badly scored.

It would appear advisable to abandon the pipe line laid in 1930 and to lay a new intake. It would prove expensive to gain access to the present line to make repairs and the intake line is improperly laid and many breaks may exist.

We would recommend the laying of a new intake from pump to a point about 500 feet into the lake. This new line to be 4" anthracite pipe and to be protected by well fitted cribwork for at least 100 feet from the pump house. The new crib work would commence with the old cribwork and would be from 5 to 6' wide. Sir:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of September 1st enclosing copies of two letters from the Secretary, Department of Indian Affairs - one letter of which, dated August 25th, relates to the procedure to be followed with respect to the water intake at the R.C. Indian School at Kenora.

This letter apparently was written previous to the receipt of my letter of August 25th in which I recommended the laying of a new intake and the repairs of pumping plant - the estimated cost being $3,500. As this amount is greatly in excess of the $1,000.00 estimated for the repair job outlined in my letter of August 13th, we will await further word from the Department of Indian Affairs. The recommendations set out in my letter of August 25th were, of course, based upon the results of examinations carried out after the letter of August 13th was forwarded.

It is noted that tenders for carrying out the work are to be asked from Mr. Charles Batchford of Kenora. Of course these instructions also relate to the repair work outlined in our letter of August 13th. It is our intention to prepare some plans with respect to the laying of a new intake but the rocky and stony lake bottom is very uneven and the exact location of the new intake would only be determined after numerous soundings were taken to ascertain the most favourable location. It is not feasible now to prepare drawings showing details sufficiently accurate to permit of tenders being called.

This work should be given to a good contractor with the necessary equipment for carrying out the job rapidly and inexpensively. The only plumbing involved is in connection with the pump. As the pipe requires no plumbers or steamfitters to connect up, Mr. Charles Batchford is a plumber and his services could possibly be utilized in connection with the pump equipment. On a small job of this kind calling for tenders would be disadvantageous. Under water work involves many uncertainties and tender or no tenders, the Government would have to pay the total cost plus a reasonable profit, since a responsible firm would tender sufficiently high to cover the uncertainties and the individual with no financial responsibility or experience would, if his tender was accepted, exhaust his resources and have to be rescued and the job finished for him.

If the Department of Indian Affairs approve of the laying of new intake and the repairing of the pump, we suggest that the work be entrusted to a good general contractor on a cost plus basis, or that a man, thoroughly experienced with such work, be selected to superintend and direct the work. This office will endeavour to give engineering assistance and to check labor and material costs.

If this work is to proceed we would appreciate receiving early advice regarding the carrying out of the same and also as to the arrangements for providing the monies necessary.

Your obedient servant,

J. T. Johnston, Esq.,
Director,
Dominion Water Power and Hydrometric Bureau, OTTAWA.

I have for attention your letter of November 28th with enclosed copy of letter from the Department of Indian Affairs returning to this office the account of Moore's Taxi Limited for services rendered in connection with the construction of the new water intake at the Roman Catholic Indian School near Kenora, Ontario.

We are forwarding herewith revised statement of the account of Moore's Taxi Limited - this statement outlining the services rendered, the weight of goods transported, the corresponding freight classification and the rate per hundred pounds. This rate classification is the same as that of the railroads and the rate per hundred pounds is also the same, as is required by law.

Replying to the third paragraph of Mr. MacKenzie's letter, I would point out that it was more economical to utilize the services of Moore's Trucking Service than it would have been to have used the facilities of the Canadian Pacific Railway. The Canadian Pacific Railway does not provide any trucking facilities between Winnipeg and Kenora. It would have been necessary for the Cartage Companies to have picked up all supplies and deliver the same to Railway Freight Office in Winnipeg and this service is not rendered free of charge by any means. At Kenora the Roman Catholic Indian School is situated over two miles from the Town of Kenora and approximately two and a half miles from the Canadian Pacific Railway Depot. Accordingly, it would have been necessary to hire a Cartage Company to transport all these materials from the Freight Sheds to the school grounds and back again. This would have been approximately the amount of the freight charges. Furthermore, in this particular instance, rapidity of delivery was of major importance.

I would also point out that the rate charged by Moore's Service was from point of pick up to the Indian School and that the same rate by railroad only applies from freight shed in Winnipeg to freight shed in Kenora.

Your obedient servant,

D. B. Cow,

SIR:

Attention: Mr. Wilkinson.

I have your letter of December 17th returning the account of Crane Limited covering fittings required for the Roman Catholic Indian School near Kenora, Ontario.

An order was placed with Crane Limited for certain fittings for the Roman Catholic Indian School on October 26th and due to an error on their part, one item on the order was not forwarded. This error proved to their satisfaction the next following and they forwarded the fitting stating that they would pay the express on the same. However, it was sent Collect and the $35 express was paid by Mr. Wallace who included it in his expense account in the regular way. We asked Crane Limited to forward us a Credit Note of $35 and this accounts for the necessity of the Credit Note.

Crane Limited were asked for the Credit Note about November 1st, it being explained that their account could not be forwarded to Ottawa for payment without the Credit Note being attached as we do not carry any accounts with the firm. It was promised immediately but it had to be drawn to their attention twice afterwards before it was finally sent. It was then sent to the office of the Department of Indian Affairs at Ottawa on Nov. 14th, receiving the balance of the last week. Their account amounts to $80.55 with $5 discount if paid by November 20th. We make it a rule to take advantage of all such discounts and in this instance were prevented from doing so by the delay of the Company so that we think it justified to subtract the $5 discount on $81.55 or a discount of $35. This discount together with the $35 Credit Note reduces the amount of the account to $80.55.

I trust that the above explanation will clear up any misunderstanding with respect to this account and we are now returning the account and would request that the Department of Indian Affairs be asked to pay the same at their earliest convenience.

Sir,

In connection with the recent construction of the water supply intake pipe at the Roman Catholic Indian School at Kenora, I enclose herewith a blue-print showing the construction as carried out by the General Contractors, Messrs. Lindstrom & Nilson of Kenora.

As you will observe from the details of the drawing, the intake extended out into the Lake of the Woods for a distance of about 750 feet from the pump house, the intake consists of 4" Universal Cast Iron Pipe and the intake follows as closely as possible the contour of the lake bottom. In order to overcome failures of other pipelines that were installed, precautions were taken at this time to support the pipe at sections where the bottom was shelving or very uneven. At the shore end of the intake it was also necessary to provide protection from freezing covering those intervals when the lake would be drawn down to its minimum stage at elevation 1056.

Copies of this blue-print have also been sent to the Principal of the school and to the Indian Agent at Kenora.

Dear Sir:

Replying to your letter 129-1-5 of 17th inst returning Voucher #8561 in favour of Heating and Mining Supplies Ltd., for repairs to pump at Kenora R.C. Residential School for $124.80.

We return the Voucher as requested, with the account dated, and also inclose receipt for the Taxi fares.

On looking over our files we find that the account was received by us in 1934 and sent to the Principal of the school on August 6th. We received no other indication the amount was owing till the other day, and discussed the matter with the Principal, who requested us to send in the account for payment as the work had been absolutely necessary.

The Principal is quite prepared to take the amount and allow it to be deducted from that authorized for general repairs during the present fiscal year.

Dear Sir,

Reference your letter 129-1-5 of August 7th, which informs us that an amount of $300.00 is available for repairs etc. at the Kenora, R.C. Residential School.

The Reverend Principal has been in to see us today and informs us that ventilators are urgently required and windows fixed in the pupils dormitories, as there are now more children in the dormitories than in previous years and also that the windows be made to open for easy exit, in case of fire. Mr. Phelan understands the situation.

We will be glad to have authority to have this work done, and to employ Lindstrom & Nilson who are on the preferred list and who have done work at this school before.

Dear Captain:

I hereby wish to present to you my report on the inspection made of the St Mary's Indian residential school.

The premises were found in very good order and well kept; the fire extinguishers were found in want of recharging and the new ones were also in need of charging; the firehose on the water standards are useless and four reels need new hose; the hose rack in the basement should also have a fifty foot length of rubber lined treated hose. Fire drills should be held regularly and from both the dormitories and the school rooms at different intervals.

One employee should be put in charge of all the fire protection apparatus including the looking after the exits and condition of the fire escapes to keep them free from snow or ice during the Winter months and free from obstructions at all times. The night watchman's clock routine should so be arranged that all doors leading to exits could be kept unlocked during the night hours; if one or two pupils act unruly in this respect they could be penalized instead of having to keep the doors locked endangering the lives of the whole of the pupils in case of an emergency or a fire.

SELECTING A POWER PUMP

In the selection of a Power Pump the questions of efficiency and cost of operation have an important bearing and in the variety of types and sizes listed herein, prospective buyers will find the power requirements of these pumps in line with greatest economy. There are several types of Reciprocating Power Pumps on the market, but the Duplex and Triplex are most used. The Gardner-Denver Duplex will handle a third more water than a triplex with the same size cylinders, both pumps operating at the same speed. This is due to the fact that the duplex is double-acting whereas the triplex is single-acting.

Gardner-Denver Duplex Power Pumps operate with highest mechanical efficiencies resulting in low power consumption. A duplex power pump will operate under a wide variety of pressure conditions with little change in efficiency, and capacity can be varied over a wide range by changing the stroke.

Estimates and complete engineering information will be promptly furnished upon request. Inquiries should include complete information as to the type of power available for driving the pump.

SUGGESTIONS FOR ORDERING

The Pumps shown on the preceding pages are such as will ordinarily meet most requirements. Our patterns are subject to various changes, all of which could not be shown in this catalogue. If, therefore, the pumps listed will not answer your purpose, write us stating the conditions fully, and we shall be pleased to submit quotations on pumps to meet your requirements.

When in doubt as to the particular type of pump suitable for you, it is well to give us the information indicated by the following questions:

1. For what purpose is the pump intended?
2. What is the liquid to be pumped? Is it cold, hot, gritty, acid or fresh? Does it contain alkali?
3. What is the average quantity to be pumped per minute or per hour?
4. State to what height the liquid is to be lifted by suction. What is the diameter and length of the suction pipe? What is the temperature of liquid? When hot water is to be pumped, the difficulty of lifting it by suction increases as the temperature increases. Hot water should always flow into the pump. See chart on page 26.
5. State to what height the water is to be forced or give maximum pressure in pounds against which the pump is to operate. The pressure in pounds per square inch of a column of water is equal to the height of column in feet multiplied by 4.34. A rough estimate is one-half pound pressure for one foot head. This allows for ordinary friction. The height in feet of a column of water is equal to the pressure in pounds per square inch multiplied by 2.31.
6. For STEAM PUMPS What is the available steam pressure at the pump? If you do not know, give us the boiler pressure and the size and length of the steam pipe. To obtain the steam pressure necessary for pumping against a pre-determined water pressure proceed as follows: Multiply area of water cylinder by the water pressure per square inch, add from 20 per cent to 40 per cent (for positive pumps) or 30 per cent to 50 per cent (for plunger pumps) then divide by the area of the steam piston. The result is the steam pressure per square inch.

7. For POWER PUMP If pump is to be motor driven state the characteristics of the electric current available. If alternating current, state cycle, phase and voltage. If direct current, advise voltage. If you prefer to furnish your own motor, certified drawings of the motor giving frame number, speed and characteristics, must be sent so that proper gears and motor supports for the outfit can be selected. It is recommended that wherever possible motors be sent to us for mounting so that proper alignment of the motor gears may be assured before drilling for the motor feet. We cannot drill holes for the motor unless the motor is sent to the factory for mounting.

Be careful to order a pump large enough. It is better to have surplus capacity than not enough. Normal and maximum speeds are given in all tables, but pumps should not be operated at more than specified speeds when absolutely necessary; pumps that must be run at high speeds to fill the requirements will wear rapidly and the saving in first cost is then far lost through the expense in repairing that will be necessary to keep it in good condition. A slow piston speed is desirable particularly when pumping against pressure and when pumping heavy liquids, also with high suction lifts and long suction lines.

All references in this bulletin to illustrations shown are to be understood to represent the type of machine and general construction only and not the exact details of construction which necessarily vary somewhat in different sizes of machines of the same class.

A correct drawing of any individual pump will be furnished upon application.

Dear Sir;

The Grand Jury in making their report to Mr Justice MacKay, yesterday, report; in connection with the two Indian Residential Schools in Kenora, as follows:

St Mary's Industrial School (R.C. Residential School.) The school was found to be well managed. The building is in urgent need of painting and decorating throughout. The fire hose condemned by the Fire Marshal should be replaced. The fire extinguisher should be re-charged at least once annually. The last inspection was in December 1933. They also require new enamel plates and cups for dining room use. One verandah needs a new roof, and one more fire escape is needed in the girls dormitory.

Cecilia Jeffrey Indian School. The school appeared to be well managed, and the pupils contented. We found that no dormitories are provided with direct fire escapes. The existing fire escapes in center of building should be repaired. Floors in all dormitories and class rooms should be covered with linoleum.

In reference to the above reports;-

The painting, decorating, and floor covering does not come under me, as all estimates come under the Inspector now, and not through this office as we do not see them.

No Fire Marshall has ever to my knowledge ever inspected any of my schools, but I do ask the local Fire Chief to inspect these buildings with me annually, and to give me a written report, as to anything he considers should be done, so as to make the schools as safe as possible from fire. These reports are always sent to Ottawa, and most of his recommendations are usually carried out.

The fire hose for the Kenora R. C. Indian Residential School is being purchased by the Purchasing Board as per Departmental letter #129-1-5 of 11th instant, and the Fire Chief has been requested to see the extinguishers are filled. Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 16th instant in which you state that the Principals of the Cecilia Jeffrey and Kenora Residential Schools do not desire to leave the dormitory doors unlocked at night.

You should refer both Principals to the instructions recently issued in which the Department expresses the definite desire that the dormitory doors should be unlocked at night. There is no reason why this cannot be done at the Cecilia Jeffrey and Kenora Residential schools because such procedure is followed at other Indian Residential Schools.

I feel certain that if the Principals give the matter further consideration they will realize that in the event of a fire serious fatalities would undoubtedly occur if the doors to the fire escapes were locked.

I trust that you will be able to advise me in the near future that the Principals of these two schools are complying with Departmental regulations in this regard.

Dear Sir,

Last Saturday night I received a wire from you, "Do you leave dormitory doors unlocked at night?" We replied, "Boys' dormitories locked, girls' dormitories unlocked."

Now I presume from your haste in a wire that you must be up against some difficulty. I have visited too good many Indian Residential schools and others in the course of my work and in some of the very best schools I notice that they lock both girls' and boys' dormitories at night. In some schools I have even noticed padlocks on the doors as the principals of these schools said these boys were experts at picking locks. We got into difficulty here some years ago when the boys' Master left a dormitory door unlocked because he had a boy who needed constant attention. While he was watching a few hours asleep three boys slipped down stairs and started a fire in the wood room and were heard returning to the dormitory by one of the men of the staff. He went downstairs to find out who had gone down, and found one of the boys still in the wood room adding coal oil to the flames.

Whatever your difficulties may be I certainly would not leave boys dormitories unlocked under any consideration. But we do leave the key turned in the door from the hall side so that any member of the staff can open them. We have not found it necessary to lock the girls in, although, they know that the same thing would happen to them if they disobeyed rules.

As for having some member of the staff sleeping in the dormitory I cannot agree with it. It is trying enough to work with these children in the daytime without having to sleep in the same dormitory and contact them all day the Indians odor from them. As for the trusted boy or girl who could have their bed close to the door I have never seen one who hasn't been sound asleep and you could have moved the whole dormitory out before they could have wakened up. I know this from years of experience and before my time I walked through this building every night and walked past every child's bed to see if they were properly covered, sometime about midnight.

If you are confronted with some difficulty do not hesitate to write and I will give you the benefit of my knowledge and experience not only as Missionary and Principal but as eight years Police Magistrate with the Mounted Police.

The best policy I know of to follow is good common sense.

With kindest regards, I remain,

Yours faithfully,

Rev. J.F.J. McFadden
Principal
happened in an Indian School, in this Agency, a short time ago, some boys having made use of a ladder to gain access to the girls' dormitory.

We have a night watchman for only six months in the year, and even when he is on duty, he has to make his inspection of the barn and the pump house, and would be away for several periods during the nights. While he was absent, the girls and boys could easily mix in the dormitories.

I have found that the strictest supervision has to be exercised at all times, to keep the boys and girls in their places, and when discussing this problem with other Principals, I find they have the same difficulties.

I hope the Department is not going to ask one School to put into practice methods, which are not required by the other Schools. I certainly would not appreciate working under such conditions, and I would like to receive further instructions from the Department, outlining how one might proceed to run a mixed school and at the same time safeguard the morals of the pupils.

The system we use is to lock the doors with padlocks, that can be removed almost as readily as turning the knob of the door. We arranged it this way, in the event of fire, so that we should feel we were using a system that would not, in any way, endanger our pupils.

I am giving your letter considerable thought, and I shall await further instructions from the Department.

I have the honor to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir:

Ref: 108-13, April 29th, 1938.

In reply to your letter, I wish to make the following observations.

In the first place, I feel that there must be some misunderstanding as to which of the doors of the school are to be locked and which are unlocked. It has always been the practice in our School to see that all doors leading to the fire escapes are unlocked during the night but the dormitory doors have been locked. I notice, in your letter, that you state that the procedure followed at other Indian Residential Schools, is to have the dormitory doors unlocked. I have communicated with six different Indian Residential Schools and inquired regarding their procedure, and they all inform me that they lock their dormitory doors at night.

In addition to this, I have visited some other Indian Residential Schools, and they, too, locked their dormitory doors. In fact I do not know of any Indian Residential School that does not lock their dormitory doors during the night.

I would very much appreciate having the addresses of some of the Schools, which leave their dormitories unlocked, so I would like to communicate with them, with a view to obtaining their methods of keeping the boys and girls under control. I cannot devise any plan that I feel would work satisfactorily with unlocked doors, and I think that it would be asking something very unfair, to a member of the staff, who was trying to obtain a night's rest, to be responsible for the boys and girls in dormitories with unlocked doors. She would not only have to be responsible for those in the dormitories, but she would also need to be on guard against young men, who visit these Indian Schools, and watch for some opportunity of obtaining entrance to the girls' quarters. Dear Sir,

I am in receipt of your letter 129-1-5 of 25th ultimo, re looking dormitories at residential schools.

I wrote a letter to each Principal asking them to as far as possible carry out the Departmental instructions, and enclose replies from the Principal of the Kenora R.C. and Cecilia Jeffrey Schools.

The letter from the Principal of the Kenora R.C. School is pretty hard to understand, but from what I can gather he puts hooks on the doors that could be pushed out in case of emergency.

As regards the Cecilia Jeffrey School the Principal apparently got in touch with other schools and asked what they did. I enclose his letter to me and also copy of a letter sent to him by the Principal of the Sioux Lookout School.

If hooks were put on the dormitory doors, that could be pushed open by the pupils in case of emergency, I think this would answer the purpose, so the pupils could escape should there be a fire, without danger.

Mr. Byers was very positive that no schools left the dormitory doors unlocked at nights and wanted me to tell him the names of any that did; I informed him all I knew was what the Department informed me, and also that the Sioux Lookout School did not lock the girls in, he said he could not trust the girls any more than the boys, but I said if he punished them severely for leaving the dormitories at night without permission he would soon stop the trouble, but he said this was impossible.

Shall I give the schools definite instructions to carry out orders or what action should I take.
