Dear Sir,

On my inspection trip to the Kenora R.C. Indian Residential school, in company with Mr John Kelly, the Boiler Inspector, I found Father LeMire now installed as Principal.

I know the Father well, he is a young man and full of ambition for the school, and I would like to help him if at all possible.

He has men making repairs to parts of the building, and informed me he was going to send me the bill for materials. I informed him I had no authority to purchase anything, or to certify to any accounts for materials or labour.

He also informed me he required paint for the school, as it required painting inside and out. This is quite true; as it looks very badly at present, and much damage is being done by the weather, on account of the paint being worn off, and some of the buildings never having been painted.

I am informed the Principal wants to get the following:
400 lbs white lead, 1 barrel linseed oil, 1 barrel of turpentine, 5 gal linseed, for outside work, and the following for inside work: 20 gal flat paint, 20 gal enamel, the school would furnish the labour and coloring material.

He is also anxious to get battleship linoleum to floor the Principal's room which is 13 feet by 16 feet, and an extra four yards for patching in the hallways.

Estimates are not put in through this office now, but through the Inspector in Winnipeg, and if only part of the material were delivered now it would be a help; the school re-opens 1st September and the Father would like to do as much as possible before the children get back from their holidays.

An early reply will be appreciated.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]
Indian Agent.

August 26, 1938.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 17th instant with reference to the Kenora Indian Residential School.

As you were informed in official letter of May 6 only $400.00 was specifically provided in the current year's appropriation for repairs and improvements at the Kenora School. This amount will be required to cover the cost of the new engine about which you were written on July 27 and August 19. Under these circumstances it is not possible for the Department to provide any funds for the repairs which the Principal wishes to make nor for the purchase of the material required to paint the exterior of the school.

You should point out to the new Principal that while certain repairs and painting are possibly quite necessary at the same time funds have to be provided before such improvements can be approved by the Department.

We will endeavour to provide in the appropriation for the fiscal year 1939-40 the amount required for painting the exterior of the Kenora School.

Yours truly,

P. Edwards, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Dear Sir:

Reference to letter 129-1-5 of 19th inst. and Letter 129-1-5 of July 27th re new pump for the Kenora R.C. Residential School.

The Reverend Principal was in the Office today and informs me that they wish to keep the old pump in case of emergency and to install the new pump, it will require a new building or a concrete basement at the old platform.

This would cost a considerable amount and the Principal has asked us to wait till Brother Gauthier comes here when he will give us all the particulars required.

Under the circumstances I do not think I can do anything further, until Brother Eugene arrives when the particulars can be got from him.

Dear Sir,

Enclosed please find the Boiler Inspector's reports on the boilers at the several Indian Residential Schools in this Agency.

The Inspector says the boiler used for the laundry purposes at the McIntosh School is much too small for the work, as the school has been enlarged, and he advises a larger boiler be installed.

He also recommends a manhole be fitted in the cold water storage tank at the Cecilia Jeffrey School. Whilst in Winnipeg he called at the Manitoba Bridge and Iron Works Company and explained what was required so a man could get into the tank and clean it out. I am asked to request the Principal to send on the stamping on tanks etc., so they will be able to supply what is required. I am asking Mr. Myers to do this and send me a copy so we will have the information on file when required.

The Inspector says the matter should be attended to at once as he noticed much deposit accumulated in the tank that already had a manhole, and the storage tank will have much more deposit in it and cannot be cleaned out.

The uptake pipe, i.e., the straight pipe lengths between boiler and smoke stack of the heating boilers at the Sioux Lookout School must be removed as it is much polished and they will be unable to continue with same during the present heating season.

Kindly send instructions as regards the above matters.

Yours very truly,

Dear Sir,

I have received a copy of the Grand Jury's report, which has been handed to me by the Local Registrar of the Ontario Surrogate Court.

In connection with our Department the report states as follows:

"ORILLIA INDIAN SCHOOL."

"Pon visiting this Institution we were met by Principal Eyers, who conducted our tour of inspection in which we found the following matters to be in order:

"The sleeping quarters of both the boys and girls new mattresses are badly needed for the beds; this is considered by the Grand Jury as an absolute necessity for sanitation.

"Upon enquiry we found these mattresses have been in use for some ten years.

"In this school we found 132 pupils, 67 girls, 67 boys, with one lot of a staff. We make special mention of the splendid art exhibits and manual training exhibits of this school and also desire to congratulate this school on the production of such a splendid Indian child.

"In the general line up of this school we found that the entire building, both interior and exterior is very badly in need of paint and should be taken care of at the earliest possible date. The condition of the present school is such that a complete paint job should be a profitable investment as there has not been a drop of paint on the walls since the school was built ten years ago. In addition to the walls and woodwork inside being in a deplorable condition, the exterior woodwork is beginning to decay for want of paint preservation. This we strongly feel is a matter that should be looked after by the Department of Indian Affairs without delay.

"We found the children clean, happy and well governed in all departments.

"ST MARY'S INDUSTRIAL SCHOOL."

"Visiting this school we were met by Father J. Lakeres (J. Lekire) who conducted our tour at this point. We found the same condition in this school, as in the other schools, in so far as need of paint is concerned. This school also must have paint inside and outside without delay for the preservation of same.

"We found 94 children in this school, including the kitchen and dining room we found the ceiling in bad condition, the plaster being cracked. However, the beds and mattresses in this school are in fine shape, the mattresses being new.

"The paint which we have to draw your attention to is the fire escape which is unsafe owing to the fact that it passes several inches from the paint above and for that reason if a fire should break out on the first or second story the escape would be cut off by the fire and out of these windows on the way going down. The landings of the fire escape are also in poor condition and would recommend that your Fire Marshall view this and place his report with the proper authorities.

"At this time we might also point out that the appropriation of the Department of Indian Affairs is made in March of each year and would therefore suggest that the foregoing request be placed prior to that date."
Ottawa,
November 10, 1938.

FIRE DEPARTMENT

KENORA, ONT., November 5th 1938

Captain F. Edwards, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ontario.

Dear Captain:

After our inspection tour made yesterday at the St. Mary's Indian residential school, I wish to make a number of recommendations which I am sure will greatly assist to make the conditions there much safer and more satisfactory in connection with the fire escapes which should also meet with the approval of the recommendations made recently by the visiting Jurymen.

The windows that would cause trouble if a fire occurred can be made safe to prevent passage danger on the fire escapes if they were equipped with wire glass and metal covered. There is also a small door outlet from the South side of the basement which comes out almost immediately beneath the base of the fire escape on that side of the building; this door should be made of metal the same as an ordinary fire door including the door frame. On the North side there is a large double door that is situated almost beneath the fire escape; this door leads out from the boiler room and would cause serious trouble and make this escape impossible to use; this door way should be made fire resistant as possible.

The stay bolts on the top of the escape on the North side are loose and require new fastenings.

The two fire escapes have electric light sockets at the outside doorway; these sockets should both have a light in them that would burn nights, and they should be on a separate circuit from the house circuit.

Provision should be made to have auxiliary lights kept ready in this building in case the power went out on the electric lines leading to this building; the pupils would not only have a difficult time to get out in the dark if the lights were out but there might occur a panic which would cause probable loss of lives.

The premises were found in very excellent condition and all appliances in proper order.

Yours very truly,

F. Dubois,
Chief Fire Dept.
I got the local Fire Chief to visit the schools with me and enclose herewith his report on the R.C. Residential School. He had not made any recommendations on the last visit to the school to cover the recommendations he now makes.

The loose stay bolts, etc., should be removed from the outside doorway, and all other defects will be attended to in due course.

Sincerely,

Frank Edwards

KENORA, ONT. January 10th 1939

Captain F. Edwards,
Indian Agent,

Dear Captain:

After the recent fire at the St Mary's Indian residential school the Father in charge has asked me to help him out in figuring out how much hose and the amount it would take to reach the largest buildings on the premises from the pump house on the water front; this will take at least five hundred feet (500) of one and a half inch hose and this size of hose can be procured from seventeen cents per foot for the linen unlined forestry type of hose, to the cotton rubber lined hose which costs somewhere around eighty cents per foot; the latter kind is of course the best hose for fire purposes and if looked after will last around ten years or so, while the other line will last only for a certain period as the starch in it gradually wears off and then the hose has no body to it, it therefore is practically useless for fire purposes.

After making a special inspection of the premises I certainly would recommend that good hose be purchased and be placed in a convenient place for immediate use and I believe that along with a good fire drill and proper instructions along fire fighting activities among the older boys and the male help around the school very efficient work could be accomplished in case of fire. Several extinguishers require refilling and this should be done at once as they were used on the fire just lately.

I remain yours as ever,

Chief Fire Dept.
Kenora, Ontario,

Dear Sir,

The Principal of the Kenora R. C. Indian Residential School, informs me that the grates in the school have burnt out.

On taking the matter up with the Campbell Heating Co., of this Town, I find we supplied new grates in December 1933 at a cost of $256.20 but the Company say that prices have dropped, and they can supply what is required at a cost of $235.00. This appears to be a very big expenditure so soon after the other grates were supplied, and there is no reason why, with reasonable care, they should have been burnt out so soon, as the School only burns wood.

However, the Principal has not been at the School long and the engineer they have there now, was away for some years so neither of them can be blamed.

Campbell informs me the reason the cost of these grates is so high is that the original makers of the boiler are out of business, and the grates have to be specially made. The last lot we got weighed over 1050 lbs.

I shall be glad to receive your instructions.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Could you let me know as soon as possible if the Department will be able to supply the materials required for building the staff residence at the Kenora school.

I regret that it will be impossible to pay for the material for the staff residence from the 1938-39 appropriation. At the present time it is doubtful if we will have sufficient funds to pay for expenditures already approved.

Recently we received a letter from Indian Agent Edwards enclosing a list of the materials required for the staff residence. If the materials were supplied it would involve an expenditure of approximately $1700.00 and in addition the Agent states that while the school authorities will be responsible for the ordinary labour it will be necessary for the Department to employ and pay for the services of a foreman and possibly a couple of carpenters.

In view of the contents of your letter of the 16th instant I am advising the Agent that the provision of the materials for the staff residence will be delayed until the matter has received further consideration.

I note that you expect to be in Ottawa about the end of the month at which time the matter can be discussed further.

Yours truly,

My dear Mr. Phelan:

I have yours of the 8th instant regarding the improvements to the Kenora Residential School. Pardon me for not acknowledging it sooner.

There is no doubt that something should be done immediately at the above school to provide accommodation for the staff.

You will remember that the staff residence was destroyed by fire last January and that nothing has been done so far to replace it. We are now studying the possibility of a small addition to the school which would serve the purpose of a staff residence. Separate staff houses have their advantages but they also have their drawbacks, particularly in the matter of heating and general upkeep. We find that in Western Canada, where the weather is extreme, the heating of the staff houses is a serious problem. If attached to the school the premises could be heated from the same boiler with a consequent material saving in fuel cost.

We have asked our own engineer to suggest the best method of providing quarters for our employees and as soon as I have received his report I shall communicate with you.

Yours very truly,

Memorandum:

Re: Kenora Indian Residential School,
Kenora Indian Agency, Electoral
District of Kenora-Rainy River.

The residence used by several members of
the staff at the above-mentioned school was de-
stroyed by fire last fall.

The Roman Catholic Church authorities, who
are associated with us in the management of this school,
consider that instead of erecting a new separate building
for the staff it would be preferable to make an addition
to the school. This would permit a re-arrangement of
the rooms and would provide staff rooms, and in the new
addition would provide class rooms and accommodation for
vocational training.

The Church authorities recommend a wing 60' x 34'
consisting of a basement and one floor -- all fireproof
and ventilated.

Rev. J.O. Plourde, O.M.I., on behalf of the
Church authorities, advised me recently that they were
prepared to undertake this work and they estimate that the
new wing can be completely built for an amount of $8000.00.
In erecting the building in this manner, with the Church
authorities handling the work, I feel that there would be
a considerable saving.
Funds for the above-mentioned amount of $8000.00 are available as follows:

(a) $3000.00 in the main appropriation for Indian Education

(b) $5000.00 in the Special Supplementary appropriation.

I, therefore, recommend, for the approval of the Honourable the Minister:

1. That the Roman Catholic Church authorities be authorized to proceed with the erection of a wing consisting of basement and one floor 60' x 34' as an addition to the Kenora Indian residential school, the material to be purchased by the Church authorities from firms on the approved list and the labour to be engaged by them, it being understood that as many Indians as possible will be given employment.

2. That the funds for the above expenditure be charged as follows:

$3000.00 to Vote 162 -- Indian Education

$5000.00 to Vote 526 -- Special Supplementary.

Director.

To the undersigned,

Indian Affairs Branch,

I have the honour to report that I visited the residential school at Fort Severn on November 5th, 1936.

Upon my arrival at the school, I found that considerable building had been done at the school, in the form of new additions.

This is the first indication I have received that any improvements have been made, and I am glad to see what is being done to improve conditions. In looking over the school, I believe I may be able to make some recommendations.

I was very pleased to find that the school is well kept and the buildings are in good condition.

I am confident that the young people who attend this school will benefit from the improvements that have been made.

Very truly yours,

Dear Sir,

Doctor A. D. Ferguson informs me he has been to
the Kenora R. C. Indian Residential School, and there are
twenty-six cases of intestinal flu at the school, and
two pupils taken to the Hospital.

He is not yet sure how bad these cases are, but
in any case the sewage disposal bed is overflowing and a
quantity of the matter running out and into the lake.

This is a matter that should be attended to at once,
and I would suggest the Dominion Water Power and Reclamation
Bureau at Winnipeg be communicated with at once and an
Engineer be sent here at once to do what is necessary, as
the outlet is not very far from where the Town gets their
water supply.

You will no doubt remember we had trouble with this
bed some years ago, and considerable expense was incurred in
making it better.

The school was originally built for only 25 pupils
and with the new buildings now authorized by Ottawa, things
are going to be worse, unless something is done to take care
of the sewage disposal, as was pointed out in my letter to
you a few days ago.

Please let me have your instructions as soon as
possible.

Yours very truly,

Extract from Doctor Ferguson's report for the month of November:

There was an epidemic of dysentery at the R.C. Indian Residential School due, I think, to the drinking water. There were 50 cases all told, some of these had haemorrhage from the bowels as well as dysentery. The septic tank and filter bed are not functioning properly. There is a break somewhere between the syphoning chamber and the filter bed so that the sewage does not go through the filter bed, but runs direct into the lake. It has cut out a small channel between the filter bed and the edge of the lake. The intake pipe for the water supply is 125 yards off shore. I am of the opinion that some of the raw sewage finds its way into the pipe line, polluting the water, and is pumped up to the school. I have taken the precautions to have the water supply chlorinated, which is being done at present, but think that the septic tank and filter bed should be examined by a sanitary engineer. I may state that this raw sewage is being discharged into the lake one third of a mile above the intake pipes of the water supply of the town of Kenora, so that there is some danger of polluting Kenora's water supply.

---

Extract from Indian Agent's letter dated December 11, 1939:

In reference to the remarks re the Kenora R.C. Indian Residential School:

I have been to the school today with the Doctor and Doctor Moseley of the Ontario Department of Health and the Provincial Sanitary Inspector. They inspected the sewage disposal and I informed them what Mr. Rose the Engineer had said in reference to the sewage liquid coming out of the bed. No doubt you have now received Mr. Rose's report.

They seemed satisfied but have asked the Doctor and Sanitary Inspector to take some more samples of the water and send them to Fort William to be analyzed, which will be done.

The septic tank and filter bed are apparently working satisfactorily now, but we don't know if this will continue.

When we arrived at the school they were having some trouble and pumping out the tank as it was stopped up and getting a large quantity from the laundry, being washday. However this will be attended to, apparently some paper or other material had got in the pipes.
In reference to your letter, dated March 12th, 1939, No. 129-1-5, regarding supplies purchased from the Kenora Company, I wish to call your attention to the fact that the prices charged by this firm are upwards of 10% higher than current retail prices.

Will you please advise if competitive prices were secured from other local firms including Bergman & Nelson and J. P. Williams & Company.

The disposal tile were dug up at a couple of places and it was found that about 1/8 inch of slime was collected in the bottom. The excavation holes were left open an hour or more and there seemed to be no change in water level which stayed at about half way up on the tiles. Possibly laundry water made this occasion one of the worst. However, since this bed has been in operation about eight years, it is believed all the tile should be lifted, trenched a foot below tile level and this lower section of the trench should be refilled with broken stone or coarse gravel. It is estimated that this would cost $250.00 were it done in the summer time when the school's sewage system could be shut down.

The settling tanks and siphon seemed to be functioning properly and had been cleaned during the past spring. As 16 inches of floating sludge had collected in the septic or upper settling chamber in less than six months, the Principal was advised that this tank should be cleaned out immediately and subsequently twice a year, as long as this excessive accumulation was obtained. It was found that the screen in the manhole above the septic tank had disappeared and the Principal was advised that this should be replaced. If this screen was cleaned regularly, the top scum accumulation in the septic tank would most likely be much reduced.

The present sewage disposal system was remodelled about eight years ago to provide for a total school population of 85 which has since been increased to about 100 and a further increase to 120 is contemplated. A new south wing of three-storeys has been added to the institution this year. It may be then more disposal area will be required and the nearest area is about 350 feet to the northwest. This area would be of ample size but pumping may be required as none of it is lower than the bed at present in use. However, it may be found that the school drainage can be separated for its easier use. Laundry and kitchen water might well be handled by this separate system, including a tank which could be located high enough to use the new disposal area mentioned.

MEMORANDUM:

Mr. D.B. Gow

Re: Kenora Indian Residential School,
Sewage Disposal System.

On December 4th an inspection was made at the Kenora School to find out particulars of overflow from the sewage disposal field. Along the lakeside of the disposal bed, leakage liquids were trickling down through rocks and coming out on the flat sloping rock ledge 20 feet from the water's edge and extended 20 feet across the length of the bed. This leakage amounted to about one gallon per minute.

It was learned this flow ceased at times but was most noticeable on a day such as a Monday when laundry work was going on. There was partial absorption by the bed.

The break had been caused several years ago when surface drainage, following an unusual storm, had washed out a triangular section about 25 feet along the front of the bed. This was cut in about six feet back from the front and was deep enough to wash out two 25-foot lengths of tile. The break had been filled in - mostly with rocks dumped in the pit.

To complete the inspection, sufficient stone was removed to get at the tile and plug sacks into the two lines running from the centre feeder. This seemed to stop all the overflow previously seen. As it was comparatively mild and the ground had not frozen deeply, School employees undertook to try to obtain clay to fill in the hole temporarily prevent further vent of liquids at the old break. This repair work was done in the afternoon and the following morning another visit was made to determine whether leakage had appeared anywhere else but none could be found. As the bed had really been partially short circuited until the open tile were stopped up, it was requested that a report be made of any further occurrence of leakage or seepage from the bed.

It is estimated that it would cost about $25.00 to repair the break and put back into operation the outer two lines of 4" tile in the north end of the bed. They constitute 1/3 of the total effective footage of the disposal tile. The estimate is contingent upon the work being done during the summer months. Proper consolidation, particularly in the outer bank, could not be readily assured under winter conditions.

As the second paragraph of your letter referring to this sewage plant requested an estimate of any improvements considered necessary, the system was looked into generally.

Dear Sirs:

The following is a synopsis of my work among the Indians in the Kenora and Savanne agency for the month of November 1939.

There was an epidemic of Dysentry at the R.C. Indian Residential school due, I think, to the drinking water. There were 50 cases all told. Some of these had Haemorrhage from the bowels as well as Dysentry. The Septic tank and Filter bed are not functioning properly. There is a break somewhere between the syphoning chamber and the filter bed so that the sewage does not go through the filter bed, but runs direct into the lake. It has cut a small channel between the filter bed and the edge of the lake. The intake pipe for the water supply is 125 yards off shore. I am of the opinion that some of the raw sewage finds its way into the pipe line, polluting the water, and is pumped up to the school. I have taken the precautions to have the water supply chlorinated, which is being done at present, but think that the Septic tank and filter bed should be examined by a Sanitary Engineer. I may state that this raw sewage is being discharged into the lake one-third of a mile above the intake pipes of the water supply of the Town of Kenora, so that there is some danger of polluting Kenora's water supply.

A. D. Ferguson.
Kenora, Ont., Dec. 11, 1939.

With further reference to Departmental letter #129-15 of 10th instant and my letter of the 18th instant re sewage disposal at the Kenora R. C. Indian Residential School.

Yesterday afternoon our Medical Officer Doctor A. D. Ferguson called at the Office with Mr. D. E. Moore, the Ontario District Sanitary Inspector for this District and asked me to go out to the school with them; unfortunately I was very busy at the time and said I could not get away just then, but I sent McKeirle, my clerk with them.

On their return they reported that the leaks were bad, and that sewage had been running down the bank and onto the ice, travelling about 150 feet from the shore, which will cause a serious situation to the town in the spring, if nothing is done.

The Doctor and Inspector suggest that outside toilets be built for the boys, about a five or six holes, and that chemical toilets be installed inside for the girls and staff.

The sewage running the ice should be scraped and all matter and ice that is discoloured should be removed and buried.

The Inspector recommended to the Principal that the chlorine contents be increased, and the Principal has promised to see this is done. I am also informed that the Doctor is arranging for the town water supply to be chlorinated a little more.

The Doctor apparently visited the school, as Medical Officer for the Town and not as Medical Officer for our Department.

On his return yesterday he promised to give me a report but today when he was in the office and I asked him if he could give me a written report, he said that I had more time to do this, and that I was Officer of Health for the Indians and not him, and that I should have gone to the school with him and made out my own report, he refused to make one out. In order to make a disposal field, runs from the base of the wall to the lake shore then on to the ice. No doubt some of this sewage finds its way under the ice as raw sewage does not freeze readily. The ice for a distance of 75 feet from the shore is discoloured brown, the tank flushes twice a day, two streams about what would pass through a four inch tile in less than half an hour. The upright of the pipe line for the school water supply is about 130 yards from the shore upstream from the condition described above so that I do not think there is very much danger of polluting their own water supply providing the pipe line is intact. I am enclosing an analysis of the water supply from the Provincial Department of Health at Ft. William, which speaks for itself.

Under instructions they are boiling the water at the school at present. I checked on the school staff re: Typhoid Fever, and there is no person there who has had it so that eliminates the danger of a carrier.

Down stream from where the sewage is running onto the ice the school have taken out their ice supply for the coming winter. A distance of about 100 yards from where the sewage discharges on to the ice. The Cameron Camps are situated about 200 yards from the town. There was another pipe line built by the city for toilet waste. The Kenora intake pipes for their water supply go within about 100 yards to a half a mile of the sewage, but the current is not direct. Two weeks during the spring and at the time break-up of the ice there will be freezing conditions of this discharge so that there will be intermittent flow. The dilution is fairly weak and the water supply of the Town of Kenora is heavily chlorinated. Cameron Camps use the Town of Kenora water supply, but there is considerable bathing and fishing near the shore around these camps. It is impossible to take a permanent job of the sewage system during the winter, but I feel that if an epidemic should arise this spring from the water supply in the Town of Kenora it would be a black eye for the tourist business in this part of the country.

I suggested to the Father at the School and Capt. H., the Indian Agent, that chemical toilets be installed in the house or the barn, however, I believe that the boys at the school will be able to get by without them. I am enclosing a report on the health of the camp.

Dear Sirs:

Recently, there has been some difficulty experienced in the disposal of the sewage from the above school. I understand that this is normally taken care of by a septic tank and a tile bed which has been constructed rather close to the river's edge. During the present winter the tile bed ceased to function, and the sewage was discharged directly into the river. Not only does this involve the water supply for your own school, which, I understand, is taken from the lake, but it also tends to pollute the lake from which the Town of Kenora derives its municipal supply.

It is difficult to reconstruct a bed of this kind during the winter time, but we should like to know what plans you have for taking care of this as soon as weather permits. Sir:

I have for attention your telegram of February 23rd and also your letter of the same date enclosing correspondence relating to the R.C. Indian School near Kenora, Ontario.

Under date of December 18th last we forwarded to you a report on the situation at the R.C. Indian School near Kenora, following an examination by Mr. J.F. Rose of this office. It is not considered necessary that any further inspection be made at this time as conditions at the school were fully covered by Mr. Rose in his memorandum of that date.

Referring to Dr. A.D. Ferguson's letter of February 18th, I believe he is misinformed in stating that the disposal field is out of order due to breakage or displacement of the main tile line leading from the siphon chamber of the septic tank and that raw sewage takes a direct line to the lake shore and then on to the ice. He is also incorrect in stating that the greatest bacterial action takes place in the disposal bed - the bacterial action takes place in the septic tank. The discharge line from tank to disposal bed is intact and raw sewage is not discharged to the lake.

The trouble at this school is that all water used at the Institution passes through the septic tank. It is now overloaded as is also the disposal bed so that some discharge passes to the lake and on wash-days undoubtedly there is a considerable flow from the disposal bed due to its partial failure. Frequent cleaning out of the septic tank is necessary to prevent the building up of the same by solids and if this cleaning out has been carried out properly from time to time there should be no passage of solids from the tank. Cleaning of the tank is not pleasant and consequently is very seldom carried out.

The water intake was laid three years ago by this Bureau and extends about 600 feet out from the present shore line. It was properly laid out to clear water. The water of Lake of the Woods is badly polluted from Fort Frances and International Falls where no treatment of the sewage is carried out. Under winter conditions this pollution is carried into Lake of the Woods and any outbreak of typhoid fever that may occur at Kenora can quite properly be blamed on this pollution rather than on the very light pollution that takes place from the Indian School. However, the situation at the R.C. Indian School is objectionable and should be cleaned up. I understand money will be provided for this purpose this year and later on this office will forward proposals for remodelling the sewage disposal system.

T.G. Mills, Esq.,
Chief Engineer,
Engineering and Construction Service,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir;

Replying to your letter #129-1-5 of 19th instant enclosing report from the District Chief Engineer of the Surveys and Engineering Branch, Winnipeg, dated the 26th Feb.

I have handed the Principal of the Kenora R. C. Indian Residential School one copy of the report, and he thinks it will not be necessary now to install the outside toilets as he has diverted the laundry water from the school to the North so that it does not go through the septic tank, and although this water for the present is going over the surface of the ground, it will not do any harm, and when the frost is out of the ground no doubt the whole system will be put in proper shape by the Engineering branch.

As regards the leakage onto the ice, nothing can be done about this as there are no solids that came out, the liquid has stained the ice, and seeped into it, so that it is discoloured, to remove this all the ice would have to be cut away, and they have no facilities for this work, and if outside men were used it would be a very expensive proposition.

The septic tank is working satisfactory at the present time, owing to the diversion of the laundry water and is cleaned out twice a year in the spring and fall.

The Engineer's report says "There would appear to be no necessity for closing down the septic tank and it is impossible to do so without closing down the institution" but the Departmental letter says "The only remedial action that can be taken at the present time is to close down the septic tank and erect as an emergency the required number of outside toilets." The two recommendations contradict themselves.

Please let me hear from you again as to whether we should erect the toilets or not in view of the Principal's statements, I think we could save money by not erecting any, and have the Engineering Branch do what is necessary as soon as the frost is out of the ground, so as to put the whole system into good working shape.

The main difficulty now is to see that the pollution of the water does not do any damage to the Town of Kenora water supply and also the residents living near the school.

Awaiting your early reply,

Yours very truly,

Memorandum:

Re - Sewage Disposal, Kenora Indian Residential School

In reference to your memorandum of the 6th instant, and enclosure, regarding this matter it is understood here from Mr. Gow's report dated February 26th last, that although the disposal system is inadequate to handle the total flow in all cases, it is only occasionally, such as on wash days, that trouble would ensue, if the septic tank were cleaned out frequently. According to the Agent's letter the tank is cleaned out only twice a year and the wash water is not diverted before reaching the septic tank which is contrary to instructions issued by the Ontario Department of Health.

Regarding the fifth paragraph of the letter from Indian Agent Edwards, a careful perusal of Mr. Gow's report would show that although he did state there was no necessity for closing down the septic tank (if it were cleaned out frequently) and that such action would necessitate closing the school, in the preceding paragraph he suggested the erection of outside toilets which would enable the school to operate even with the septic tank closed down.

It would appear that the recommendations made by our engineer have not been followed in that (a) the septic tank is not cleaned out frequently, (b) the outside toilets have not been erected and (c) the wash water is not being passed through the septic tank.

Respectfully submitted,

Chief Engineer.

Memorandum:

Mr. Wardle

Re - Sewage Disposal, Kenora Indian Residential School

In further reference to our memorandum of the 10th instant, Mr. Gow has reported under date of the 15th instant that he visited the school on the 8th and 9th instant and was informed that the outside toilets had not been built as the Board of Directors of the school had obtained approval from the Medical Health Officer to discharge laundry and kitchen waste into the lake without passing them through the septic tank. This can be considered only as a temporary expedient as the discharge is along a slight depression and creates an unsightly nuisance in front of the school. He is going to interview the District Sanitary Engineer and try to obtain authority to divert all laundry and kitchen waste permanently to the existing siphon drain. The estimated cost of this drain is $600.00 and alterations to the plumbing in the building will cost an additional $100.00. The total cost of this and re-conditioning the disposal bed will be $1,000.00 instead of the $225.00 which has been provided.

Mr. Gow is being asked if, with the proposed diversion of laundry and kitchen waste, the present disposal bed will be adequate when the new wing, now under construction, is completed.

In a report prepared by Mr. Gow in 1931 it was pointed out that the school building had been so located that only one small area was available for use as a disposal bed. This appears to have been developed to the fullest extent and if it is found necessary to construct other disposal beds, the effluent from the siphon chamber will have to be pumped.

Any further information received in this connection will be forwarded to you promptly.

Dear Sir:

I would like to call your attention in a special manner to the new wing-unit which was erected last fall to the Kenora Indian Residential School.

When this new unit was first contemplated, the school authorities had in view the replacement of the old staff building, which had recently been destroyed by fire. But since its erection it has been thought feasible to use it as dormitory accommodation for the school children instead of staff quarters. The staff are all adult persons and can more easily save themselves in case of fire; besides they are willing to sacrifice their own comfort in order to provide fireproof dormitory accommodation for the children.

Unfortunately the funds provided last year were only sufficient to erect the walls and roof in the new unit; nothing whatever was done to finish the inside of the building. There are no finished floors, no electric light, no heating and no toilets; the walls themselves are not even plastered.

Could you suggest a method whereby this new unit could be completed this year, so that it could be used for dormitory purposes? Very Reverend Father Lamontagne, Provincial, is willing to supply all the labour, free of charge, in connection with the plumbing, heating and electric wiring.

As these are three of the principal items of expense the department might be able to find a method, whereby sufficient funds could be allotted to this project to complete it by next September.

Hoping that you will give this matter your serious and early consideration, I remain,

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

INSTRUCTIONS RE RENDERING OF ACCOUNTS FOR TRAVELLING EXPENSES

1. Copies of Accounts.—The number of copies will vary with departments but the original and one copy are required by the Representative of the Treasury.

2. The Treasury Regulations provide that an officer—
   (a) Who travels continuously shall render an account and refund any unused balance of advances within ten days after his return.
   (b) Who holds a standing advance must render a monthly account within ten days of the end of the month.

3. All accounts must show, in detail, the actual expenditure incurred and must be reasonable in view of all the attending circumstances. Expenditure designated "sundry" or "petty expenses" cannot be allowed.

4. Receipts—
   (a) Receipts must be submitted to cover all items in an account except those for railway, steamship or bus fares, meals, telegrams, telephone calls, local taxis and tips.
   (b) Receipts should be on the bill head of the payee or written by the payee, numbered consecutively in the order charged on the account and the numbers entered in the "Voucher Number" column.

5. Meals—Hotels—
   (a) If European plan, the charges for meals shall be entered in the "Meals" column, with the price of each meal entered on one line in the "Details" column, e.g., B.—L.—D.
   (b) If American plan, the whole bill shall be included in the "Hotel or Lodging" column.

6. Transportation—
   (a) The column "Transportation, berths, etc." shall include railway, steamship and motor bus fares.
   (b) When the travel is by railway, steamship or motor bus, the time of departure and arrival to and from each place visited is to be shown on the account.
   (c) Unless specifically authorized, charges cannot be allowed in excess of:
      I. First class transportation, when travelling on railway, and the equivalent, when travelling by water.
      II. In all cases, where practicable, travel is to be by the shortest direct route; return tickets shall be purchased and advantages taken of reduced fares, special rates or limited tickets.
      III. Lower standard berth, when travelling by railway sleeping car, and the equivalent, when accommodation is on shipboard.
   (d) When incurred on department requisition, the serial number of the requisition is to be entered on the expense account.

7. Taxis, Livery and Auto Hire—
   (a) Points between which they are used must be stated. When two or more officials are travelling together, separate charges cannot be allowed, unless the necessity for the employment of separate vehicles is stated.
   (b) Mileage charges for a privately-owned automobile can only be allowed when the use of such car on government business has been authorized previously by the deputy head in accordance with the regulations.

8. Gratuities—
   (a) Gratuities for meals shall be included in the charges for meals.
   (b) All other gratuities shall be entered in the "Other Expenses" column and details given indicating to whom paid, e.g., porter, bell boy, etc.

9. Telegrams and Telephones—Charges for telegrams and long distance telephone calls should be supported by stating the name and address of persons telegraphed or telephoned.

10. Claims for loss of personal effects or for medical and hospital treatment cannot be included in any expense account. Such claims must be submitted through the department to Treasury Board for approval before payment.

11. Expenses connected with stop-overs at resorts and other places, while not on duty, cannot be allowed.

Replying to your letter of July 12th re the above school, enclosed are two sets of prints from measurements, two photos and the following report.

The building extension is 60 feet long by 34 feet wide, and 9'10" by 37'6", two storeys and basement, with an additional boiler room 20 feet by 34 feet one storey.

The exterior walls above basement are of old and new common brick as indicated on prints and clearly shown on photos, exterior walls are of 8 inch brick backed up with 4 inch hollow tile.

Windows are 1-3/8" sliding sash without weights and all doors where indicated are 5 panel common fir doors, the doors between old and new building are intended to be changed for fireproof doors.

In a general survey of the construction, I consider much of it is very satisfactory, particularly referring to the brick and tile walls, also the concrete floors and concrete to roofs. The basement walls are not yet furred with hollow tile and much of the concrete is roughly poured.

Under the boiler room floor are three lines of glazed drain pipe which should be of iron.

There has been no proper supervision of related sections, viz no sleeves are installed in any part of the building for plumbing pipes, heating or water pipe or electrical conduit; this will entail much unnecessary drilling of concrete and brick work.

One unfortunate feature is the seepage of water to East wall of basement; part of the basement wall is built directly on rock several inches above the floor level, this part of the basement will be permanently useless unless a rock channel is cut below basement floor level for a distance of 44 feet.

Dear Mr. Jackson:

I am in receipt of a letter from Mr. Hoey, Superintendent of Welfare and Training, with reference to the addition erected at the Kenora Indian Residential School.

While it is true that the addition is larger than was originally intended I feel that such action was justified due to the fact that the present building is by no means fireproof and the addition which was erected is absolutely necessary to provide fireproof dormitory accommodation for the pupils enrolled at this school.

May I be permitted, in this connection, to call your attention to the following paragraph of Mr. Parkinson's report, copy of which Mr. Hoey forwarded to me:

"Referring to the cost of work to date, $12,188.95, I have carefully checked this over and find the amount very reasonable. I believe the contractor took advantage of cheap winter labour; checking back on a cubic foot basis, the rate is 15¢ per foot."

Mr. Parkinson estimates that in order to make the building habitable a further expenditure of $18,000.00 would be required.

The Oblate Order is prepared to finance the proper completing of the building immediately. We estimate that we can handle it for $8,000.00 and are prepared to give a definite assurance to the Department that if the expenditure for plumbing and heating, electrical work and fixtures, plaster, woodwork, flooring, stairs, painting, fire doors and tile drain exceeds this amount the Oblate Order will pay from its own funds the excess amount over $5,000.00.

Will you please note the attached letter from Reverend Father Plourde in reference to the addition to the Kenora Indian Residential School. Father Lamontagne and Father Plourde called at the office and discussed the matter with me at some length. I made it quite clear to them that the Minister had only approved of an expenditure of $8,000 on the building and that when the approval was first obtained the building was not to cost more than this sum. I explained, however, when we were advised last Fall that the cost had been exceeded, an additional $4,000 was provided in this year's estimates and that this was the only sum now available to pay the outstanding accounts, or to pay any accounts that would have to be incurred in the future to complete the building. I did not hold out any hope that funds would be provided in next year's estimates to carry out the proposal set forth in Father Plourde's letter and stated that if the Church wished to complete the building they would have to do so at their own expense without any promise from the Department that they would be reimbursed for any expenditures made.

In discussing Father Plourde's letter with the Minister he approved of using the amount provided in this year's estimates, namely, $4,000 to pay the accounts that are now outstanding.

When you are through with Father Plourde's letter, will you please return it.

C.W. Jackson,
Chief Executive Assistant.

Your letter of August 13th has been brought forward for attention. In it you indicate that you then shortly expected a report on the Kenora Residential School from your architect. It is assumed, of course, that the architect has completed his examination, allowing this account, which is now nearly twelve months old, to be paid. My dear Mr. Hoey:

October 22, 1940.

Dear Father Plourde:

I have your letter of the 17th instant with reference to the completion of the unit at the Kenora Indian Residential School.

Since your visit to the Department the outstanding accounts have been paid and the amount provided for this purpose in the current year's appropriation is practically all spent.

It was not found possible, when preparing our estimates, to include any amount for the completion of this unit, although I am hopeful that funds will be available for the provision of heating equipment and possibly some other equipment during the fiscal year 1941-42.

I am sorry that I cannot be more encouraging in this regard but you will realize that conditions under which we are working at the present time are most unusual.

I feel, however, that it is most important that this unit should be completed at the earliest possible date. As you have previously been informed it is the express desire of the Department that the new unit will be eventually used for dormitory purposes only. We cannot give approval for the use of the new unit for any other purpose.

Yours truly,

Rev. J.O. Plourde, O.M.I.,

Memorandum:

Dr. McGill

Re - Septic tank, Kenora Indian Residential School.

A report has been received from Mr. Gow, under date of the 15th instant, that he found it impossible to undertake the repairs, to the extent of the $300 provided, at the above School before it opened on September 4th and that it is much more difficult to undertake the repairs when the School is in full operation. His limited staff has also been very busy.

We are obtaining further information from Mr. Gow, but under the circumstances, it appears this work will have to stand over until next year.

I am quoting herewith from Mr. Gow's letter regarding sewage disposal conditions:

"In all probability this school will be able to operate this winter continuously, although there may be the usual complaints from the Ontario Health Department about pollution of Lake of the Woods and there may be also complaints from the school management in connection with difficulty of getting rid of the kitchen and laundry drainage."

We will arrange to return the $300 made available if, in Mr. Gow's further report, he confirms our understanding that nothing more to advantage can be done at this time.

[Signature]

Dear Sir:

I beg to acknowledge yours of the 22nd instant regarding the new unit at the Kenora School. Please accept my sincere thanks for having settled the outstanding accounts incurred for the construction of this unit. I sincerely hope that you will be able to find funds to provide the necessary heating equipment.

I note your remark in the last paragraph of your letter regarding the use to which the new unit is to be put. I quite agree with you in this respect as it would not seem logical to have the children sleep in the old building when fireproof dormitories could be provided in the new section of the school. May I be permitted to say that, as I am not directly in charge of the Kenora School, it might be advisable for the Department to write to Rev. Father Lamontagne, the Provincial of the Manitoba province, and to Rev. Father Lemire, the Principal, to advise them of your wishes in this matter.

Thanking you very kindly for what you are doing for Kenora, I remain,

yours very truly,

J.C. Lourde, O.M.I.

Re: Sewage Disposal, Kenora Indian Residential School.

In reference to Dr. McGill's memorandum to you of October 28th last, stating that it was essential that the work be done this fall, and that if necessary, funds in addition to the $300.00 already transferred, would be provided. Dr. McGill has informed me today that the re-conditioning of the sewage disposal bed has been completed except for levelling off the surface, replacing the sod and sodding the slope of the bed. Soil and sod were frozen solid and could not be worked up.

In addition to the work on the sewage disposal bed, all kitchen and laundry drainage was connected to one main sewer and this was extended to a new drain which extends about 190 feet from the building. This is only a temporary expedient to care for this waste until a disposal system satisfactory to the health authorities can be developed. The cost of this work was $193.00 which includes $77.15 for materials.

The total cost of the work at this school including the kitchen and laundry waste but exclusive of the engineer's expenses, $228.75, which are being met from Vote 76-33, amounted to $363.45, made up as follows:

Labour - $844.35
Material 118.04
Telephone 1.06

Will you therefore kindly arrange with Dr. McGill for the immediate transfer of $65.00 which will be required to pay accounts for materials already purchased.

Dr. McGill might also be informed that the levelling and re-sodding of the sewage disposal bed will have to be undertaken early next season at an estimated cost of $75.00.

It might be noted that if it had not been for the expenditure on the kitchen and laundry waste, the $300.00 provided for the re-conditioning of the sewage disposal bed would have been ample for that purpose including the work necessary to complete it next spring.

Respectfully submitted,

Dear Sir;

Last Fall I have made a new bridge on a new road to the School. I have taken the opportunity to make this new road, because the bridge of the former road being no more good. With this new road now we arrive in front of the School instead of the back.
The said bridge have cost me $93.80 for lumber only, and a few more dollars for nails.

Dear Sir:

Enclosed please find tenders from the J.H. Ashdown Hardware Ltd., Crane Limited and Marshall-Wells Co. Ltd., all of Winnipeg, on the boiler and material needed to install heating in the new wing of the Kenora School, and to effect the necessary changes in the existing heating plant.

It is understood that the Oblate Fathers will supply the labour necessary to install this plant. As the summer season is already far-advanced, we would ask the Department to purchase the above material without the least delay, so that the plant can be in operation as soon as the cold Fall days begin.

As the funds available for this work may not be sufficient, the Oblate Fathers agree to advance the amount necessary to complete the purchase of the material needed on the understanding that whatever moneys are thus advanced will be refunded during the coming fiscal year. Should you find it impossible to promise the refund of excess expenditure, may we suggest that you nevertheless allow the Fathers to proceed with this work, and that the purchase of part of the radiation be left in abeyance until the Department is in a position to complete the purchase of same.

Our Brothers will be available to undertake this work within two weeks and we would like the material to be ordered immediately, so that the work will not be unduly delayed. Of course almost no delay would occur if you were good enough to allow the Oblate Fathers to place the order with the lowest tenderer. We would naturally be guided in this connection by any advice from you and invoices would be rendered directly to the Department.

Yours very truly,

Honorable Sir:

AGENCY MINISTER,

You will recall that last year a large addition was built at the Kenora Indian Residential School, in order to provide fireproof dormitories for the pupils in attendance at that school.

The amount provided did not permit the installation of proper heating facilities, and the Reverend J. O. Plourde, C.M.I., acting on behalf of the school management, has secured tenders from the following firms:

1. Marshall-Wells Company, Limited,
2. Crane, Limited,
3. J. H. Ashdown Hardware Company.

I attach these quotations for your information.

The lowest tender is that of the J. H. Ashdown Hardware Company, which totals $4,542.87. In the current year's appropriation we have provided an amount of $3,500 for repairs and improvements at this school, and the balance that will be required to provide the heating installation that is necessary could be taken from an unallocated amount in our appropriation.

The Oblate Fathers will supply all labour necessary to install this plant, without cost to the Department. The new wing is a very substantial building.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER,

You will recall that last year a large addition was built at the Kenora Indian Residential School, in order to provide fireproof dormitories for the pupils in attendance at that school.

The amount provided did not permit the installation of proper heating facilities, and the Reverend J. O. Plourde, O.M.I., acting on behalf of the school management, has secured tenders from the following firms:

1. Marshall-Walls Company, Limited,
2. Crane, Limited,
3. J. H. Ashdown Hardware Company.

I attach these quotations for your information.

The lowest tender is that of the J. H. Ashdown Hardware Company, which totals $4,542.97. In the current year's appropriation we have provided an amount of $3,500 for repairs and improvements at this school, and the balance that will be required to provide the heating installation that is necessary could be taken from an unallotted amount in our appropriation.

The Oblate Fathers will supply all labour necessary to install this plant, without cost to the department. The new wing is a very substantial building and will...

Dear Sir,

I am in receipt of your letter of January 6th inst., in connection with the new wing built at the Kenora School for dormitory purposes.

I wish to state that until now, some work has been done in this unit in order to be used by the School for temporary purposes only.

In September 1940, our Lay Brothers have fixed storm windows and doors, finishing coat of cement on floors, installation of a few toilets and temporary electrical wiring. This year, they are working on the heating system and the work will not be finished before a few months if it is at all possible during winter months to make the necessary connection with the new boiler.

In a letter addressed to you on Nov. 15th 1940, I said: "May I add, this new unit will require a rearrangement of several of the departments of the school, and before any changes are made, the Principal and the Mother Superior will submit a complete plan to the Department for its official approval." No alterations of any kind have been made until now in the old building, and it has been possible to remove only one dormitory in the new wing.

I desire to reassure the Department that no alterations will be made for the new rearrangement of the school, before being submitted to the Department for its official approval, and I request that an official of the Department be sent when convenient to study his new setup with the staff of the school.

I wish to assure the Department, of my entire cooperation in all that may be for the greatest welfare of our Indians.

Yours very truly,

Dear Father Plourde:

I desire to refer to your letter of the 9th instant with reference to the Kenora Residential School. It is noted from the last paragraph of your letter that you hope that funds will be provided in the coming year's appropriation to plaster the walls and ceiling.

I am advised by the Minister's office that a very definite understanding was reached with Father Lamontagne and yourself to the effect that the Church authorities would assume a considerable portion of the cost of completing the new addition to the Kenora School. The Minister originally agreed to an expenditure of $8,000.00 and later approved an additional expenditure of $4,000.00. Since that time he has also authorized funds for the new heating plant. This makes a total expenditure of $16,310.99.

If the Department could accede to the wishes of the Principal and agree to complete the building, a great deal would be accomplished towards removing from the minds of our Catholic Indians, and from those of local friends of the R.C. Indian Residential School at Kenora, the impression that, in comparison with the Cecilia Jeffrey School, the former seems to have been treated pretty much in the manner of a stepchild.

Back in 1928, when it was decided to change the sight of the Cecilia Jeffrey School, a beautiful farm was bought as a new sight at a cost of $12,000. In the following two years at least $170,000 was spent on the construction of the new School. Moreover about $5,500 were allowed for the purchase of farm implements and livestock. Besides the Kenora R.C. School only received $180.00 per year per pupil, whilst $165.00 was being paid to the Cecilia Jeffrey. This discrepancy in the grant lasted until the attention of the Department was called to it. You also know, no doubt, that the pupilage of the Cecilia Jeffrey is 150, but that of the Kenora R.C. School is only 95.

It must be remembered that both the Cecilia Jeffrey and the Kenora R.C. School cater to the same group of Indians, most of whom are of aboriginal belief, and I still can't figure out why the Department adopted the policy of erecting such a large School for the Cecilia Jeffrey group and refused to enlarge or rebuild the Kenora R.C. School.

All this is brought to your attention not in a spirit of recrimination, because after all you had nothing to do with the condition which now prevails in that district, but it will supply you with arguments to use when this matter is again brought to the attention of either the Minister or his Executive Secretary. You could spend a large amount of money on the Kenora R.C. School and it would still be in an inferior position to the Cecilia Jeffrey. The policy of the Department has always been to treat both the Catholic and non-Catholic elements with equal fairness and the present may be an opportune occasion to remedy a condition which is apt to leave doubts in the minds of some regarding this determination of the Department to treat all denominations on an equal basis.

I remain, my dear Mr. Hoey,

Yours very truly,

Dear Sir:

I have yours of the 20th instant regarding the Kenora R.C. Residential School. Whilst it is true that the Government has already expended a fairly large amount towards the building of a fireproof wing to the above School, the fact must not be lost sight of that the Oblate Fathers themselves have contributed a fairly substantial amount in the form of labour. Under present conditions it would seem almost unfair to ask them to complete the building at their own expense.

This new addition, as it now stands, is larger than was originally planned; on the other hand, it will provide fireproof dormitories for all the children of the School. This improvement could not have been secured if the original plan had been strictly followed, and is an aspect of the problem in which the Department cannot but be very much interested, as the danger from fire to the lives of our Indian children must be eliminated wherever possible.

Bearing these facts in mind, we still believe that the Department should not refuse to appropriate at least part of the funds necessary to complete the building. As it now stands, neither the walls nor the ceilings are plastered, and whilst you have asked the School Principal to use both the first and second stories for dormitory purposes, and he is willing to comply with your wishes, you will admit with me that dormitories with such bare walls and ceilings are not very inviting.

And may I add the following remarks:

Dear Mr. Roberts:

I wish to submit to you my report on the inspections we made recently at the two Indian residential schools near Kenora.

In the St. Mary's School the extinguishers that require recharging each year should be done; the others do not need to be done only require an examination to see that the hose carriage of the outfit is in good order; alterations on the fire escapes are needed and there should be a fire alarm both in the dormitories as well as in the classrooms. A hose reel should be installed with all the equipment so that all the hose could be available quickly for fire fighting. For the outside of the building and other buildings on the grounds, the pipelines from the main pump should be so arranged that it could be connected to in suitable places, the older boys could be instructed on how to allow all the fire fighting equipment to be used in case of necessity. This is one reason why equipment is kept in such a condition to be used quickly when necessary.

I have also noted that the fire escape doors and windows are not open outwardly; approaches to escapes should be on a level with the escape doors. The doors of dormitories should be left open so that they can be taken off easily in case of fire. I have also noted that the walls of the dormitories are very dirty and the floors are very dusty. It is important to keep the dormitories clean and the floors swept regularly.

I am enclosing a list of recommendations which I believe will be helpful.

Yours sincerely,

[F. Dubois]

To the Honourable Mr. Justice Fulton, Judge of the Supreme Court of Ontario:

May it please Your Lordship:

We, the members of the Grand Jury, present at the meetings of the Supreme Court of Ontario at the Court House, October 8th, 1942, beg to present the following report:

Kenora General Hospital

We found this institution to be well managed and in fine condition in all departments. We consider the housekeeping to be very good.

St. Joseph's Hospital

Your Jury also found this hospital to be well managed and in very good condition.

In both hospitals there were several cases which should have been just as well cared for in a suitable home, thus leaving more room for those needing hospital care. We would recommend that as soon as possible, measures be provided to prevent the occurrence of similar cases in the future.

Provincial District Jail

We found this institution to be in excellent condition, but we regard the inmates as being ill-treated. We found that the food prepared was not fit to be eaten. Some of the prisoners were very weak and appeared to be suffering from poor treatment while in custody. We urge that immediate steps be taken to improve the conditions of the inmates. We also recommend that the authorities give full attention to the complaints made by the inmates regarding the manner in which they are treated.

GLORY BE!

FOR FLAKIER BISCUITS, USE

Cecilia Jeffrey Residential Indian School

We found this school to be in good condition. The food provided was adequate, and the living quarters were clean and comfortable.

St. Mary's Residential Indian School

The living quarters were clean and comfortable, but the food provided was not sufficient. We recommend that the authorities provide better food for the students.

Court House

The court House is kept in excellent condition and can readily be seen to be in good order. Our only recommendation is that a separate lavatory be provided for women. All of which is respectfully submitted.

March 27th, 1945.

With further reference to my report dated today, March 27th, on the St. Mary's Roman Catholic School, Kenora, your file 1291-68, I think it only fair to outline certain other work and expense incurred by the school but which has no bearing on the accounts at present under consideration.

1. All basement windows are being screened; frames bolted together and covered with mink wire; each frame costing approximately $4.00.

2. A special bathroom has been constructed to be used by all. It is called a heat bath, and the idea is to heat the room, causing one to perspire. This removes dust and cleans the pores; then cold water is used as a shower.

3. Two large outdoor swings were built last fall. Each garden swing seats about six pupils. They are well made and strongly bolted together. Probably cost $60.00 each - totalling $120.00.

4. The Principal has purchased four good cows and three heifers; three hundred chickens; and two horses, at a total cost of almost $1,000.00. He is trying to provide milk, butter and eggs enough for the school and some to sell. The team of horses were made necessary because he had to haul the school wood a distance of sixteen miles.

5. There is constant repair work and the carpenter, in addition to special jobs, attends to the general upkeep of the building and equipment.

Father Comeau showed me a bake oven which he intends to install shortly. The present oven is too small, making it necessary to bake every day. The room now used as a bakery is part of the hall way. It is small, dark and when the oven is on the heat is almost unbearable. The Principal states he is building an addition to the kitchen which will be used for the bakery and it will also house the electric refrigerator. The refrigerator at present is in the upper part of the furnace room and the motor is running almost continuously. I understand even though no authority is granted for expense in connection with this work, that Father Comeau considers it absolutely essential and intends to proceed.
He also wants the new wing plastered. At present the rough tile and bricks present a very dismal appearance. The walls are rough and ideal for collecting all dust. The steel construction work holding the floors is open with not even the metal lath on. This, too, is a wonderful place for dust and almost impossible to clean. This wing is a very valuable addition to the school and if possible it should be completed. The doors leading from the old building into the new wing are ordinary wooden doors. These fire-proof doors should be provided. These, in case of fire, would prevent smoke and flames reaching the stairway down which the children must pass to escape. If authorized, I can secure prices for these doors.

This school is well operated. The children have good clothes, are well fed and appear very happy. I understand there are 110 pupils although the ground is paid for only 75. This excess number of 35 pupils makes a further heavy drain on the principal's finances. He explains there is no other schooling accommodation provided for the children and he feels they are entitled to an education.

I trust this further information will help to provide some light to the financial problems of this school.

A.G. Hamilton,
Inspector of Indian agencies for Manitoba.

report as follows.

I went through the list of materials with Father
Comeau and am convinced the same were largely used either in
the new fireproof wing or in the re-modelling of the old
buildings. I find one exception in that some of the lumber was
used to complete the chicken-house. This two-storey building
is 16' x 48' with capacity for about four or five hundred hens.
I am aware that the Department purchased some material; but
unfortunately the quantity requested was underestimated.

The school's donation to this program of work
consisted largely in the giving of labor. Father Comeau claims
the plumbing labor was donated. He claims this work, if
contracted for, would have cost at least $500.00 or $600.00.
All the wash basins were transferred from the old building, and
the broken ones renewed; toilets were installed both for the
children and supervisors, and this all joined up to the main
outlet. I am not a plumber; but I am convinced the work is
well done and I am also convinced that it entailed many days of
labor.

Father Comeau has a carpenter on the staff and this
man, along with some of the big boys, did most of the painting
after the chapel was re-modelled. Contract labor for this work,
it is estimated, would have cost at least $350.00. The school
carpenter also assisted odd days throughout the entire recon-
struction period; but no record was kept of the labor.

The carpentry work consisted of the building of
a supervisor's room in one dormitory, together with cupboard
space for clothing. In all, three large rows of storage space
were provided, with doors and lockers.

The old classrooms were re-modelled and are now the
chapel. This work meant taking out partitions, removing the old
chimney, putting in heavy beam supports for the upstairs floor,
and re-flooring places previously used as toilets; and in some
cases re-plastering walls or renewing them with wallboard. A
new wall was required along the sewing-room, and certain altera-
tions made to the room used by Father Comeau as his office and
bedroom.
The old dormitories were altered to be used as classrooms. Repairs were needed to the walls and floors. Blackboards were installed, also a number of fluorescent lighting fixtures. Good lights were made necessary because the windows are dormer windows and the sunlight cannot spread about in the same manner as with the ordinary window.

As stated above, I feel convinced that the materials listed were all used to good advantage, and I am sure if the alterations had been carried out by contract a much greater expense would have been incurred.

The accounts enclosed with your letter are being returned herewith.

A.G. Hamilton,
Inspector of Indian Agencies for Manitoba.

In March of the current year Father Gomseu left a number of new accounts for further material and labour amounting to £475.69 and asked that they should be paid by the Department. These accounts were sent to Inspector Hamilton at Winnipeg and he was asked to make an inspection of the building. His report disclosed that in addition to the construction of a new fireproof wing, the old classrooms were remodelled and turned into a chapel. He stated that the work meant taking out partitions, removing the old chimney, putting in heavy beam supports for the upstairs floor and re-flooring places previously used as toilets and in some cases re-plastering walls or renewing them with wallboard. I have outlined at some length all of the facts because I wished you to know what had taken place in the past and the reasons why the Department cannot keep on paying the accounts that are submitted from time to time. The work approved of in the first instance was the construction of an addition to the main building to provide quarters for the staff, owing to the destruction by fire of their old quarters. The cost was estimated at £10,000 by Father Plourde. If I had known the expenditure would exceed this sum approval would not have been given because of the conditions existing at that time. Mr. Norman Paterson, Indian Agent, Kenora, Ont.

I have your letter of the 11th instant, enclosing plans and estimates from Lindstrom & Nilson and Bergman and Nelson with regard to the erection of a brooder house at the Kenora Residential School. The quotation of Lindstrom & Nilson is the lower, but in their specification dated November 3 there do not appear to be any arrangements made for ventilation under the floor. In addition all Government publications regarding construction of such buildings suggest the advisability of a concrete floor instead of a wood floor. Before submitting the matter to the Minister's office for consideration this Branch felt that the plans and quotations should be returned to you, in order that you may reconsider the points raised in this letter, as, if our suggestions are carried out, it will make a considerable difference in the type and quantity of materials that would be needed.

You should point out to the Principal that I am not in a position at the present time to promise him definitely that the expenditure will be allowed, but, as intimated in the preceding paragraph, we want to have everything in proper shape before submitting it for a decision. I also enclose, for your information, a copy of a booklet issued by the Department of Agriculture and you will note on Page 8 of this that they strongly recommend concrete floors.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Mr. Norman Paterson, Indian Agent, Kenora, Ont.

Since writing to you yesterday I have reviewed the last annual report of the Kenora Residential School and, according to the information given by the Principal at that time, there were the following outbuildings:

- Barn: 60 x 20
- Piggery: 10 x 10
- Hen-house: 40 x 16
- Shops: 20 x 38
- Sheds: 40 x 15, 20 x 30
- Implement shed: 30 x 34
- Boat houses: 40 x 15, 20 x 50 x 12

You will note from this list that the Principal stated they had a hen-house 40 x 16. If this building is in good condition we feel that a brooder erected according to the attached plan would be much cheaper and almost as satisfactory as the larger one suggested in the correspondence to which we replied yesterday.

On considering the matter again we also feel that it would not be very satisfactory if a brooder were built and used for pigs this winter and then for hens next summer. It is our opinion that the same building for pigs and hens is not very suitable.

With the above in mind we thought it advisable to write to you again and, before replying, you and the Principal should give very careful consideration to the points raised both in our letter of yesterday's date and this letter.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dear Sir:

Please find enclosed the plans and estimates for a chick-brooding house.

This building is of absolute necessity at St. Mary's Indian School. Actually, there is no room provided for the 600 chicks we have to buy every spring in order to keep the flock in a good laying condition.

Furthermore, this building would be used this very fall to winter twenty-five young hogs we should otherwise be obliged to kill before maturity for lack of a warm shelter, and during February, it would be used for the sows and their litters.

This means a difference of few thousand pounds of pork and hundreds of dozens of eggs in the yearly product, so necessary to meet with the rationing conditions.

For this reason, I do not hesitate to make an urgent appeal to you, to obtain from the department, this most needed construction.

I am yours thankfully,
