Ret Brooder House - Kenora R.C. Indian Residential School.

Receipt is hereby acknowledged of your 129-1-5 of the 17th and 18th instant in connection with the above noted subject.

As requested, the writer checked over this proposed Brooder House plan with Father Comeau, the Principal of the school.

This building would be a permanent structure, built approximately 70 feet south of the present hen house. There will be a concrete foundation built on solid rock with a wall of cement two feet high on which the wood superstructure will be erected. The concrete sub wall would be lined with Hollow Tile. Air vents below wooden floor are to be provided and this will prevent dampness rising to the floor; and it is also planned to use the chimney as an air ventilator. In this part of Ontario where severe weather prevails, chicken and poultry owners are of the opinion that the wood floor is superior to the concrete; and the majority of the brooder houses which the writer has seen are built on this pattern.

This Brooder House is of average size and will be well constructed to take care of the 300 chicks. The chicks will be kept in the brooder house until they are three to four months old, having their own run built around the house.

Father Comeau does not intend to keep pigs in this house permanently after the chicks are out, but proposed to use it for this year as he is pressed for room in the barn.

What is listed on the Buildings Inventory as a Piggery 10 x 10 is not an out building, but a stall in the stable where the young pigs are kept at present. This barn, by the way, is only large enough for the cattle and horses now on hand. If young pigs are kept for a short time in the brooder house, a rough dwelling will be built over the permanent floor, and the house will be thoroughly cleaned out with disinfectants when pigs are removed.

I strongly advised Father Comeau not to use the proposed building for this purpose, and he stated that this was, of course, his idea as an emergency measure only. The school has suffered heavy losses in chicks during the past due to the poor quarters used; and I am sure this loss could be eliminated in the future by providing a brooder house as outlined.

I trust the foregoing will be of some help and submit same for your consideration.

[Signature]
Indian Agent.
Ottawa,
November 30, 1945.

Mr. Norman Paterson, Indian Agent, Kenora, Ont.

I have your letter of the 25th instant, in further reference to the proposal to build a brooder house at the Kenora Residential School.

The contents of your letter have been very carefully considered but it is difficult for the Department to convince itself that the Principal is making the recommendation that would be in the best interests of the work that he apparently contemplates.

The plan forwarded to you with our letter of the 16th instant outlined a brooder house which would be suitable for all practical purposes and which would only require an expenditure of approximately $125.00 for material. The building that the Principal now requests would cost approximately $700.00. It would not be any more suitable for use as a brooder house than the much cheaper building just mentioned. It is admitted, of course, that he could accommodate approximately 300 chickens in it, but it would only be necessary to keep them in such a building for a limited time. The building recommended by us would provide more opportunity for training pupils in handling chickens under conditions which they could hope to have at home. Besides, if the building recommended by the Principal were built, there would actually only be accommodation in it for approximately 50 hens.

I am inclined to feel that if the Principal wishes to raise pigs it would be much more desirable to provide some proper accommodation for them rather than the building which he recommends. Dual-purpose buildings are never completely satisfactory.
I feel that this matter should again be very carefully considered both by the Principal and yourself.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Mr. R.A. Hogg, Supt. of Welfare & Training,
Kenora, Ont.

Dear Sirs,

Mr. Norman Peterson, Indian Agent, has kindly sent me your letter of November 20th, in which you propose the building of a brooder at the cost of $125.00.

I am sorry to tell you that after having carefully considered this matter and having taken advice from different experts in poultry raising in this country, I have come to the conclusion that the building proposed by Mr. Douglas is not the proper shelter to be used as colony house after brooding time for chicks at the end of three months, but would be of no use here for the three following reasons:

1st. The Miller Co., of Winnipeg forwards their chicks in March when one week old and the latter to be kept at a temperature of 80° until the end of May, which means nearly two months of severe winter yet in this country. This will be impossible with a $125.00 building.

Actually, at the cost of labor and material, one will not be able to put more than one plinth of lumber, and consequently it will require the time of a man day and night to prevent the chicks from freezing.

2nd. The topography of the surrounding land does not allow a construction of a movable type, the School farm being built on rocks and hills.

3rd. This building is not sufficient to accommodate 500 chicks when they are two months old for then they still have to be kept in on account of the cold weather.

Let us forget about pigs,...I had to kill them being short of place.

As my chicks are ordered for next March, I consider with anxiety that time is flying. I hate to think that I will have to be in the same predicament as last year and loose half of those valuable chicks. Therefore, I am confident that you will understand my firm stand in insisting on the necessity of my request. It is in the interest of the Indian Department.

With the best compliment of the season, I remain,

Yours sincerely:

C.E. Conner

Re Brooder House - R.C. Indian Residential School.

Receipt is hereby acknowledged of your 129-1-5 of the 30th ultimo regarding further consideration and recommendations of the above noted subject.

I have checked very carefully into this matter and have arrived at the conclusion that while this is a high price to pay for a brooder house, it is none the less the type suitable for the extreme weather conditions in this part of Ontario. The plan of the brooder house submitted by Lindstrom and Milson is for brooding purposes only, and in no way adapted to protect the chicks as Colony House, or Colony House, as used in Eastern Ontario, can be moved to different locations; but this idea cannot be carried out here owing to the rough character of the surroundings and the extreme cold.

I may also add that the chicks will be housed from the middle of March until the middle of June, when they are allowed to forage and roam at will in the yard.

A letter from Father Comeau, Principal of the Kenora R. C. Indian Residential School, is attached for your information and consideration.

Although the cost of the brooder house is high, I believe that over a period of say ten years it will more than pay for itself.

Having in mind the purpose for which this brooder house will be used, and that a substantial saving can be made through curtailment of losses in chicks, I would recommend that if the full price cannot be authorized that a portion of same be allowed.

[Signature]

G.

Res Fire Protection- I.R.Schools.

During my last inspection of the Indian Residential Schools on April 26th and 27th, the fire equipment was inspected and it was noted that the 2½ gallon Fire Extinguishers were of the old type and several had been used and not refilled owing to the difficulty in procuring refills for this particular type.

The schools have at present the following number and type of extinguishers:

St.Mary's I.R.School:
- 2 Thermone Soda & Acid Old Type 2½ Gal.- Filled & in use.
- 2 Empty to be filled.

Guardene:
- 1 New Type - Filled & in use.
- 1 Empty to be filled.

It will be noted there are two Thermone Extinguishers empty. These cannot be refilled with original type of refills and can only be made serviceable by being converted to take later type of refills or replaced. This costs approximately $11.50 each, whereas a new Extinguisher of the lyrene or Guardene type would cost around $13.75 and can be refilled for $.70 cents.

There are no extinguishers in the barn or Staff House, which should have some protection, especially in the summer.

Cecilia Jeffrey I.R.School:
- 7 Thermone Soda & Acid Old Type 2½ Gal.- Filled & in use.
- 2 Empty to be filled.

These were recently converted and recharged at a cost of $11.50 each, and quite some time elapsed before they could be put to use.

Three more extinguishers are required. One in the basement hallway and two in the top floor corridors.

It appears to me that these Old Type Thermone Extinguishers could be purchased, at considerable less cost, when found necessary to have present ones converted and recharged. In doing so both schools would have similar and standardized equipments.

I would therefore recommend that authority be granted to purchase the following when it is found necessary, after being used, instead of converting and recharging these old type Thermone Fire Extinguishers:

For St.Mary's I.R.School:
- 4 Pyrene Acid & Soda 8½ Gal./fire extinguishers.
- 2 Ditte - One for barn and one for Staff House.

For Cecilia Jeffrey I.R.School:
- 7 Pyrene Acid & Soda 8½ Gal./fire extinguishers
- 2 Ditte - One for basement hallway
- 2 Ditte - One for top floor corridor

Correspondence leading up to this inspection is here-with attached. I might also add that the Kenora Fire Chief strongly advises this change. The foregoing is submitted for your information and consideration.

Norman Selby,
Indian Agent.

OTTAWA, Ontario.

The Reverend Father Comeau, Principal of St. Mary's Indian Residential School, Kenora, Ontario, was in yesterday and he is anxious to start the Indian boys raising the Giant Flemish Rabbits, to be used as meat at the school. He wants to get the boys interested in animals and is prepared to pay them a reasonable price for the meat. He thinks the revenue obtained will keep the children interested and the meat can all be used in the school.

Father Comeau estimates it will cost for breeding stock and a small log building fifty dollars ($50.00). May I be advised if the Department is prepared to assist in this undertaking to the amount suggested? Any undertaking of this nature that will keep the children interested and out of the town of Kenora will be well worth while.

A.G. Hamilton,
Inspector of Indian Agencies for Manitoba.
Ottawa, September 7, 1944.

Mr. A. G. Hamilton, Inspector of Indian Agencies,
588 Dominion Public Building, Winnipeg, Manitoba.

I have for acknowledgment your letter of August 30, in which you submit a request received by you from Father Comeau, Principal of the Kenora Residential School, for the funds necessary to purchase a number of Giant Flemish Rabbits.

I regret to state that with one single exception - that of Morley, in Alberta - the experiments undertaken by principals of residential schools in the keeping of mink and other such animals have been in no sense successful. However, this appears to be the first occasion when we have had a request for rabbits. In view of the small expenditure involved and the desire on the part of the Department to do everything humanly possible to make training at our residential schools practical and well worth while, you may authorise an amount not exceeding $50.00 for the purchase of rabbits at this school.

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Kenora Agency, September 7th to 9th.

Kenora R.C., Indian Residential School and Buildings: - The school is an old building with a new fire-proof wing recently built—used for dormitories. The old section has been remodelled and adjusted to provide ample classroom space. Rather Comeau, the Principal, is very bitter against the Branch for refusing to pay the cost of the alterations. If money is available, I would recommend that some arrangement be made. He is very pleased with the new brooder house and the grant for the construction of a pigery. The new wing has not been finished inside. Plastering and decorating should be done at the earliest possible date.

The barns and stables are all in fairly good condition. The farm is small and difficult to work, as it consists of small cultivated areas, very rocky. A great deal of hard work is being done by the Principal and his staff and they deserve a lot of credit for the good condition of the buildings and property. The vegetable garden is particularly good—consisting of every variety of vegetable that can be grown.

J.E. Morris,
Welfare Division.
FIRE DEPARTMENT

KENORA, ONT  November 25th .... 1944

Norman Paterson, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, ONT.

Dear Mr. Paterson:

Following our custom of previous years of paying occasional visits to the two Indian residential schools located just outside of our Town limits, I wish to report on the conditions found regarding the safety of the lives of the inmates as well as on the protection of the valuable property involved in these large buildings.

In the St. Mary's school the recent alterations made have interfered with the location of one of the fire escapes and also with the fire hose standards in the building; these two items should be attended to as soon as possible; there is also the need of a fire door in the door that leads to the west side boiler room and one that leads out of the Boys dormitory out to the corridor of the old building.

The fire hose connections are not connected on account of two different threads being supplied; a reducer from the two and a half inch to the one and a half inch thread connection is required, and the pupils should be given more frequent fire drills and be made acquainted with the proper handling of all the fire protection appliances and apparatus.

In the Cecilia Jeffrey school much needed alterations are required on the fire escapes particularly on the ones leading out from the dormitories; the present approaches to the fire escapes can be very largely improved upon and I would recommend that immediate attention be given to these safety appliances.

The fire alarm systems in both these schools can be improved upon especially in the St. Mary's school where the fire alarm bell most is practically useless; an alarm system should be installed which can be heard in any section of the building.

Very serious occurrences have taken place in several institutions in this Country where lives and property were lost for the want of special attention along the lines as mentioned by the Superintendents and Teachers in charge of both these institutions; I am very attentive to things pertaining to the safety of the pupils and the way have very excellent fire drill programs in operation and anything in which I can assist in this work in the two schools I am sure that I shall be only too pleased to render all the assistance I can in the interest of the safety of the inmates as well as the property concerned in these institutions.

Yours very truly,

Chief Fire Officer
Indian Affairs Branch
Dept of Mines & Resources
OTTAWA.

Fire Protection - Indian Residential Schools.

On November 23rd and 24th, the writer, accompanied by Mr. F. Dubois, Chief of the Kenora Fire Department, inspected the Cecilia Jeffrey and Kenora (R.C.) Indian Residential Schools.

Chief Dubois' report covering these inspections is attached herewith, for your information.

The fire hose connections in the Kenora R.C.I.R. School are not of one size and of very little use in their present condition. It is very important that this be remedied immediately, and instructions have been given Mr. Dubois to go ahead and have these connections standardized, and would recommend that the small expenditure to be incurred be authorized.

When conditions warrant, I would strongly urge that the major items noted in this report be given attention.

Norman Watson
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

I beg to draw your kind attention to the fact that our school, contrary to what is found in other schools, is totally lacking in accommodations for hog raising.

The high cost of living as well as the substantial aid that we would derive from hog raising make the need of accommodations for said purpose more urgent than ever. Until now we have managed under very trying and more than provisory conditions which are becoming impossible.

This requisition seems to deserve your prompt approval as it coincides with your suggestion of which in your letter to the Agent, dated Nov. 25, 1943, File No. 129-1-5, (1 quote): "I am inclined to feel that if the Principal wishes to raise pigs it would be much more desirable to provide some proper accommodations for them rather than the building which he recommended."

I am therefore forwarding plans and specifications for said accommodations. As the cold season is drawing near, I hope that my requisition will be given kind and prompt attention and receive a favorable answer.

I beg to thank you and remain

Yours very sincerely,

December 7, 1944.

Mr. Norman Paterson, Indian Agent, Kenora, Ont.

I desire to refer to your letter of October 19, submitting a request from the Principal of the Kenora Residential School for authority to construct a hog pen.

We have reviewed this request on several occasions, but, as the amount requested is rather large and no specific provision was made for it in the current year's appropriation, we have been unable to give a favorable reply. It is our intention to consider the matter further, but before doing so we would like to have an expression of opinion from you regarding the advisability of raising pigs on the scale which the Reverend Principal evidently intends. Has he feed available or will he have to purchase all the feed required? If the latter is the case, it might mean that raising pigs at the Kenora School would not be a very profitable venture. As a general rule we do not desire Principals of residential schools to go into the pig raising business on a commercial basis, as we feel that if only sufficient pigs are raised to provide food for the school elaborate buildings are not absolutely essential.

Philip Phelan,

(1) Hose connections - Chief Dubois recommends that all fire hose connections be standardized, and also that two of the fire hose reels now in place, be replaced to a more efficient service position in the building. (4) Fire alarms - A fire alarm system should be installed that could be heard anywhere in the building at a probable cost of $100.00, and an auxiliary bell in case the electric unit was out of order.

(5) Fire Extinguishers - There are twelve Soda and Acid Type fire extinguishers in the building, well placed and sufficient to take care of emergencies.

Re: Drinking Fountains for Schools.

During my inspection of the Kenora R.C.I.R. and the Cecilia Jeffrey I.R. Schools, it has been noted that the drinking water facilities are not only antiquated, but most dangerous to the health of the pupils.

This condition had been noted on previous inspections but owing to other matters pertaining to the fire protection and safety measures being brought up to standard, the report on this matter had been postponed.

The pupils at the Kenora R.C.I.R. School have access to one only water tap on the hand basin placed near the door of toilet and wash room. The pupils at the Cecilia Jeffrey I.R. School have access to much the same contrivance, placed in the dormitories alongside of the wash basins.

During the last T.B. Clinic held in Kenora, one pupil from each school was recommended for attendance to sanatoriums. In view of the unsanitary conditions of the present arrangements in both schools, I thought it best to submit a report immediately. The principals of both schools have readily agreed that a few drinking fountains placed in the most convenient sections of the schools would certainly be helpful in guarding the health of the pupils.

The Willmar Bronze Company of Kenora, have advised that a wall type of drinking fountain, suitable for the schools, could probably be purchased at a price ranging from $10.00 to $40.00 each, and would cost approximately $4.00 to $6.00 to install, by their local plumber.

The Kenora R.C.I.R. School would require 5 fountains:

- 1 - "canteen" - 1 - "playroom"
- 1 - "playroom"
- 1 - "reception room"

The Cecilia Jeffrey I.R. School would require 7 fountains, placed as follows:

- 2 - "boys' canteen"
- 2 - "girls' canteen"
- 1 - "boys' playroom"
- 1 - "girls' playroom"
- 1 - "reception room"

The foregoing is respectfully submitted for your information and I would strongly recommend that if funds are available, that these several drinking fountains be installed.

Indian Agent.

Mr. A.G. Hamilton, Inspector of Indian Affairs, C.E.C. 03 for
Manitoba, and the writer, visited the Cecilia Jeffrey and Kenora
I.C. Residential schools on the 26th instant.

While at the Kenora I.C. School, the work on the dormitories was inspected. Plastering is to commence on Monday April 30th.

During this inspection, the question of installing ventilation in
the dormitories was discussed, and it was pointed out by Mr.
Boux, the contractor, that it would be advisable to do this job
now, while he is there with his men. It was agreed that some
ventilation was very necessary. This work should be done before
the plastering is commenced, as considerable cutting through the
ceiling and wall will be necessary, and additional expense would
be incurred if it were done after all the plastering is finished.

The Fife Hardware Company was asked to install a straight
ventilator intake in the ceiling of the girls' dormitory at a cost of
approximately $60.00 and to install an electrical fan assembly
in the wall of the boys' dormitory at a cost of approximately $125.00.

Reverend Father G.E. Comeau has also asked that some
additional plastering be done while Mr. Boux has his men at the
school. This work consists of patching the ceiling in the classroom; plastering four walls of the Sisters' dining room (2x14 where
the plaster is falling off badly); plastering walls of basement

I submit the following report on the St. Mary's Indian Residential School, Kenora, inspected April 26th, 1945.

This school is allowed 85 grant-earning pupils, but the enrolment shows 96. They were all well dressed, clean and neat in appearance. The classroom work was well done and the pupils are making fair progress.

The dormitories were clean and plumbing in good condition; the new wing is to be plastered; in fact the preliminary work had started. There was no ventilation provided when the building was erected and Mr. Paterson was strongly advised to provide this at once before the weather started. He had authorized the expenditure and the ceiling ventilator was being installed on the day I arrived. I advise Mr. Paterson to notify Ottawa at once concerning the probable cost and to point out why it was an emergency. Undoubtedly the work can best be done now and the cost will be less.

The old part of the building is in poor condition and a lot of material and labor is required to put it in good shape. The floors are rough and badly worn; consequently, difficult to keep clean. A quantity of battleship linoleum should be provided. To cover the floors outlined by the Principal about $25 yards would be needed. In any event a start should be made and I would recommend the following, amounting to approximately three sixty-yard rolls, double A (AA) quality, 6 feet wide, together with felt base and cement:

When submitting my report re fire protection at the Indian Residential Schools, under 106-11 dated December 6th, 1947, it was suggested that the present fire escape on the south side of the school be extended to the ground, and fire doors installed in the building. Lindstrom & Wilson, local contractors, were asked to estimate on the fire doors to where they were there were asked to arrange for the erecting of the addition to the fire escape, and at that time gave me verbally a rough estimate of the cost, which was $100.00 or more, and a written estimate was received, Lindstrom & Wilson, fire doors, $150.00, and fire escape, $100.00. As I see it now the mistake was made in Mr. Lindstrom & Wilson giving me a verbal estimate on something that I am not familiar with, and I fully admit this was a matter, not having come to my attention at the proper time, and considerable embarrassment to all concerned and more especially to the department.

QUARTERLY REPORT ENDING JUNE 30th, 1945, ON KENORA INDIAN AGENCY

Schools:

Several inspections have been made during past 3 months, at both Residential Schools. Schools have been found to be well conducted internally, orderly and clean. New Boiler has been installed in Cecilia Jeffrey I.R. School and the boiler house has now been made clean & tidy. The old Spencer Boiler has been insulated and will be used as a stand by; hot water Tank has also been insulated.

The contract of plastering the boys' and girls' Dormitories and other plaster work at the Kenora R.C. IR School has been completed. This has made a wonderful improvement to these dormitories, and a first class job made. Two ventilators were installed, one in each Dormitory.

The Kenora R.C. IR School closed for summer vacation on the 20th June and the Cecilia Jeffrey School on the 22nd to 24th June. In this Agency, where many of the parents of pupils come long distances to get their children at school closing time, it is desirable and has been the habit in the past, to have both IR. Dear Sir,

Lately we received a shipment of paint: 25 gallons. We are grateful to the Department for this. Unfortunately, we realize that we haven't enough. Our intention was to paint the three classrooms which need a good cleaning; they are poorly lighted and the walls & ceilings are dark & dirty. Besides we have had a few cases of tuberculosis, therefore it is of the first importance to disinfect thoroughly.

For this we would need: 10 Gals. white Log-glo for the Senior class-room
10 " Junior c.r.
10 children dining room
15 other public rooms

And 5 gallons of cream paint for trimmings. In all 30 gals.

We are in position just now to do the painting ourselves; this is a good opportunity we would not like to miss.

Trusting tha this requisition will be agreeable to the Department.

I remain Yours truly:
G.E. Comeau C.M.I.
Principal.

In my report on Fire Protection at the above noted school, dated December 6th, 1944, File 108-11, it was noted therein, under heading - Kenora R.C. I.R. School -(2) Fire Escapes - that the extension to the old escape would cost approximately $100.00.

This estimated cost has been greatly underestimated. On receipt of your authority 129-1-5 dated Ottawa December 11th, 1944, Mr. Sam Onerheim was asked to go ahead with this work and the cost was based on the making of a short extension to the old escape, without the platform or bracing; and on a later check up it was found necessary to lengthen the ladder and build a landing.

On inquiring from Mr. Onerheim if this work was about finished, he informed me that it was ready to install and that his first rough estimate was far too low. I then asked him to submit a detailed estimate for the Department's information. Copies in duplicate of this estimate with a rough sketch of work is attached herewith.

It is regretted that the initial estimate was so far out of line and that I was not advised of this earlier. As this work is completed and ready to install and also that it will provide much needed safety to the children, I would recommend, if funds are available, that Mr. Onerheim be given authority to install this escape as presently constructed.

Mr. Norman Paterson, Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.

I have your letter of the 7th instant, with reference to the fire escape at the Kenora Residential School.

As you state in your letter, your original estimate was $100.00. It now appears that the total cost for the fire escape that is considered necessary will be $715.00. I note that you mention you were not advised earlier of the increased cost. Should this information have been given to you by the man from whom you obtained the original quotation, or did the Principal neglect to notify you? You can realise that the very greatly increased cost places this office in an awkward position. Is it possible to secure prices from someone else, and are you definitely assured that all the work proposed is essential?

It would be appreciated if you would give this matter very careful consideration and again consult the Principal. We realise that children must be protected, but at the same time we have expended a great deal of money at the Kenora School within the last two or three months, and even as recently as the 2nd instant we authorized additional expenditure.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Mr. Onerheim is in no way to blame, nor is Reverend Father Comeau. As I see it now the mistake was made in having Lindstrom & Nilson give me a verbal estimate on something they probably were not familiar with, and I fully admit this whole matter, not having come to my attention at the proper time, has caused considerable embarrassment to all concerned and more especially to the Department.

Re: Fire escape, Kenora R.C. I.R. School

Receipt is hereby acknowledged of your 129-1-5 dated Ottawa May 12th, in connection with the above noted subject.

Further to my 106-11 dated the 7th instant, wherein I had explained the discrepancy in the original estimated cost of the escape, and the last detailed cost as given me, by Mr. Sam Onerheim, I would like to add these further comments and explanation.

When submitting my report re fire protection at the Indian Residential Schools, under 106-11 dated December 6th, 1944, it was suggested that the present fire escape on the south side of the school be extended to the ground, and fire doors also installed in the building. Lindstrom and Nilson, local contractors, were asked to estimate on the fire doors and while they were there were asked to arrange for the erecting of the extension to the fire escape, and at that time gave me verbally a rough estimate of the cost, which was $100.00 or more. This was shown on my report.

When your authority 129-1-5 dated December 11th, 1944, was received, Lindstrom and Nilson was instructed to install the fire doors and they in turn had Mr. Onerheim check on the proposed extension to the escape. Mr. Onerheim on a later check up, found that a more substantial structure was required and after getting the material, proceeded with the construction of the escape and the landing, having understood that he was to go ahead with the job. When this work was completed I was advised by Mr. Onerheim of the approximate cost, which far exceeded the first estimate I had received verbally from Lindstrom & Nilson. I immediately had Mr. Onerheim submit the detailed cost of the escape and platform as it is presently constructed, as I knew some ball-up had been made of this transaction.

Mr. Onerheim is in no way to blame, nor is Reverend Father Comeau. As I see it now the mistake was made in having Lindstrom & Nilson give me a verbal estimate on something they probably were not familiar with, and I fully admit this whole matter, not having come to my attention at the proper time, has caused considerable embarrassment to all concerned and more especially to the Department.

Mr. Onerheim has been constructing and erecting
fire escapes for a number of years, and he informs me that the Manitoba Bridge & Iron Works, of Winnipeg, had quoted him the following prices on this work -

Construction & Erection of double railed escape - $14.00 per ft.

Construction of platform 18-6 x 6 -per sq. ft. - $5.00 to 6.00

Similar work has been done by Mr. Onerheim at the Hotel Kenricia, the Kenora Post Office and the Cecilia Jeffrey School, and as he was highly recommended by Lindstrom & Nilson, competitive prices were not asked for.

Reverend Father Comeau did not press for this much needed protection at the time it was proposed, but as Fire Chief Dabois strongly urged this, and believing it to be very essential, I recommended same in my report.

This fire escape and landing is now completed and is ready to be erected at the school, and as considerable labor and expense has been assumed by Mr. Onerheim, I would, even though admitting the difficult position I have placed Mr. Dabois in, recommend that the work be proceeded with, and you may rest assured, that in the future greater care will be exercised when asking for estimates and prices covering all work of this kind.

Norman Paterson,
Indian Agent.

Re: Floor covering for Kenora R.C.I.P. School.

Receipt is acknowledged of your 129-1-5, dated the 3rd instant, in connection with the above noted subject.

Your remarks concerning the inadvisability of covering the old cracked floors with linoleum, have been noted.

Since my last report was submitted, dealing with the floors and the necessity of having them covered, I had in mind that you had considered purchasing Double A Battleship Linoleum, and not ordinary infield linoleum. I agree that the latter type of covering would not stand up.

Double A, Battleship Linoleum, if purchased and laid, would outlast even a Maple floor. On an old floor, a coating of cement is laid which fills all cracks and depressions. Then on top of heavy felt paper is laid. It is in turn coated with the floor covering. Then the linoleum is laid.

The old floor in the agency office was in very bad shape and an excellent job was done by covering with the Battleship Linoleum.

A copy of a quotation from Lindstrom & Wilsons, of Kenora, Ontario, is attached hereto for your information.

Fir flooring cannot be purchased and if it were possible to buy, I do not think that it would be economical to lay. The hardwood flooring, if laid, would, I am sure, eventually become loose, open-jointed, and in places would wear badly. This is proved by the existing Maple floor in the school's waiting room, for which new flooring was purchased recently.

The price of $337.50 covers sufficient Maple flooring to lay on the areas which are in poor shape only. The $94.50 item covers part of main hallway in new building, which is at present covered by Fir flooring, and which is already showing signs of wear.

Were Battleship Linoleum provided, at a cost of approximately $1.70 per sq. yd., with the required amount of floor cement and felt paper, and the work of laying done by the school, it can be believed, more than offset the cost of laying Maple flooring, which if laid by inexperienced help, would only require patching and repairing at a later date.

I would therefore recommend that, if the floors of the school are to be covered, that it be done with Double A, Brown Battleship Linoleum.

The water supply at this school was inspected on February 16th, 1946.

Chlorination of the water at this school has been suspended. The only method of chlorinating this water, which comes from the Lake of the Woods, is by the old two barrel hypochlorite method. The chlorine solution is fed from the barrel through a 1/2" pipe line into the main on the suction side of the pumps. The chlorine feed is controlled by two valves on this line. This system of chlorinating water is extremely antiquated and should be replaced by a proper type of chlorinator.

The water supply at this school was also inspected on February 16th, 1946.

At the time of the inspection, no chlorine was reaching the water supply. This was probably due to the presence of sediment in the rubber hose and in the bubble jar. It is recommended that these be thoroughly cleaned. A considerable amount of trouble is being encountered at this institution in controlling the chlorine feed as, on the previous day, an excess of chlorine was being added to the water. The chlorinator is a suction type Wilson hypochlorinator.

Reverend Father C.E.Comeau, O.M.I., was interviewed last evening in connection with the water supply at the school. The chlorinating system was also checked over.

When this system was inspected by Mr.A.E.Berry on February 16th, last, the school engineer had only been on the job for a short time and had not time to acquaint himself with the water system or to adjust himself to all the conditions around and about the school. This man has since been instructed thoroughly in the maintenance and operation of the chlorine system and the regulating of same.

The water system is at present being regulated as best possible under the existing condition of this old and antiquated system, and will be watched carefully until such time as a more efficient and up to date system can be installed.

The attached letter has been received from Reverend Father C.H. Comeau, O.M.I., Principal of the Kenora R.C.I.R. School.

Both Kenora Residential Schools' night watchmen are being paid at the prevailing rate of $40.00 per month.

The watchmen, apart from their special duties of seeing to the safety of the school in general, perform various other duties in and around the school, and are a very necessary part of the school staff, and generally have taken an interest in the welfare of the pupils.

I am in agreement with the Reverend Principal's submission and would recommend that the matter of wages for both night watchmen, in the Kenora Residential Schools, be given your favourable consideration.

Dear Mr. Paterson:

RE: SALARY, NIGHT WATCHMAN.

We are submitting herewith, our invoice to cover part of wages of Night Watchman, for Jan., Feb., March, & April 1946.

While we appreciate very much the action of the department in allowing us this amount, you are, of course, aware that this does not cover the Salary of the night-watchman, and that it is necessary for us to supplement this from the already over-taxed grant.

We would therefore request that you would make representation to the department on our behalf, setting out the necessity of having this man, but the impossibility of securing a man with the proper qualifications for such responsibility, with so little remuneration.

We would like to suggest that the amount of $60.00 per month may be allowed. (This is the amount which we have decided to make the minimum monthly wage for male help, when employed out of our grants.)

Yours sincerely,
